reviewText:
I should start by getting the obvious out of the way: Dark Souls 2 is a great game.

Dark Souls 2 is such a difficult title to write about. After spending an hour or so staring at an empty box, one in which is usually filled with a review, I watched dozens of Hatsune Miku music-videos. Surprisingly, this didn't give me the inspiration I needed to write. At this point, I didn't dare consider just playing more Dark Souls 2. Whenever I do that, entire days just disappear into the ether. All I really can do is will myself to push forward, and hopefully I can somehow slam enough words together to create a coherent thought.

Ugh...This is a terrible idea, I just want to keep playing DS2. The problem is that I have other videogames that need attention. Part of the reason I got into reviewing was so that I wouldn't just play the same games over and over again. So that's why I'm here today. I want to get this review over and done with so I can move on. This is not a knock against Dark Souls 2 - I have plenty of those on the way - I'm doing this out of interest in my own sanity.

Speaking of sanity, was From Software crazy when they came up with DS2's world? Since the days of King's Field, I've always appreciated From's attempts at creating cohesive worlds. Even with the knowledge that DS2 suffered through development-hell, it's still shocking just how little anything makes sense. The startling difference between Earthen Peak and Iron Keep has been mentioned before, but I'm also concerned with all of the one-way paths, narrow corridors, and overall sense of linearity.

The world-design issues result in an over-population of bonfires. This causes a loss of tension, since you rarely lose progress when you die. Without tension, there aren't any areas that I truly dread. Dread is a good thing, especially in this series. When you overcome the situations you fear the most, it feels all the more rewarding. For me at least, there were far too little of these situations in Dark Souls 2. There's no Sen's Fortress, or The Archers of Anor Londo, or even Blighttown. Actually I take that back, DS2 has the quasi-Blighttown aka The Gutter. DS2 has a lot of what I consider to be portions" of what could be great areas. If these portions were expanded upon
hoursPlayed: most of the areas in this game feel like a piece of something greater
voteText: which doesn't make for a very fulfilling experience. It should also be noted that even tiny tiny areas like Black Gulch have two bonfires.\n\nHowever

reviewText:
I'm not really sure where to start with this game, it's amazingly well made for a person to start into the series.

Of course, people who have already played the previous games may find it a little more easy than I do, because of their experience on what to do, what not to do, and how difficulty ramps up.

But what I can safely say, the combat is very rewarding and rarely ever have I died unavoidable deaths, well, besides one sort of death, falling. It's unavoidable because no matter how hard I try, I will get caught in the heat of the moment and die. But at the same time, it is usually the least punishing death, as you can, most of the time, retrieve the items you lose on death and thus lose no progress whilst trying to avoid the spot the next time.

On other notes, the games multiplayer is also, by what I've seen so far a very diverse experience, from co-operating with other people to invading them and instead, attempting to make their game worse whilst improving your own so to say.

I'd rate Dark Souls as one of the hardest games I've played in a while though, that definitely. I have died so many deaths from being stupid and dodging too early, or too late, and thus getting the full blow of an enemy's attack which then either staggers me, takes half my health, both of them, or simply instakills me because I play a very squishy build.

But all in all I can say, the game looks pretty, it plays well, even without a controller ( unlike the first, I tried it  but I couldn't continue) , has AMAZINGLY rewarding combat in my opinion.

The only negative I find in it is Soul Memory, really, due to how it can mess up matching in PvP.

reviewText:
The follow up to Dark Souls. Is it as good as the first game? Well no, but it's far from a terrible game.

This time arround the PC port is much improved, Keyboard and Mouse actually work, no modding required this time, same with the graphics. Still plently of room to prove but this port is defenantly much improved over Dark Souls port, and since this is only the second PC port From has done, I'm ok with letting the few minor issues slide. Rome wasn't built in a day after all, and one can not expect a develuper to suddenly turn out 'the best PC ports ever' after one game.

So what all is diffrent with this port. The menus are all mouse driven, the keyboard controls are all set up in a manner a normal human would use, for the most part. There's still no slotting items and spells to the number keys for quick use, probably never will be ether due to balancing reasons, and theres just a lot more options for settings and such then before. all in all not the best port, but again, a good couple sets above Dark Souls.

Now, what about the game it self?

Well, it's kind of a mixed bag.

Combat remains largely unchanged, all the skills and habbits you picked up in Dark Souls will translate, for the most part, unmolested, to Dark Souls II. For the most part, charging in and trying to face tank things with get you dropped in a hurry, and a good shield is still your best friend as is being slightly paranoid while playing. One thing they changed is what enemys spawn in groups. In Dark Souls, the much tougher enemys spawned alone  and far enough away from every thing else there was little to no chance of drawing in more enemys. In Dark Souls II this has been changed so that those tougher enemys, like the Mastadons and Everything in the Dragon Shrine spawn two or three deep. This applys to the bosses as well, as there are FAR more boss fights that involve more then one boss monster at a time, or bosses that spawn more enemys in general. The problem is, the Combat system is still only designed for one on one combat, which makes these bosses and enemys more harder then they needed to be. That said though, the game is actually easyer then Dark Souls.

This has to do with all the healing Items avaible to you, as there are ten diffrent items that restore HP in Dark Souls II, as a frame of refrence, there are only two in Dark Souls, three if you count the item that gives a temperary HP boost. No only are there a lot of diffrent healing items, most of them are in abundence, some being buyable in infinute amounts after certain points, same applys to the ores needed to upgrade equpiment, though to a far lesser degree. another thing that makes the game easyer is the 'genocide' mechanic, as I've taken to calling it. What it does is put a respawn limit on enemys, meaning if your farming souls to level up or what have you, you WILL run out of enemys to kill, after around twelve times or so. There is an Item you can use to get another twelve respawns but that also puts that area in NG+ mode, so care needs to be used lest you screw your self

Another area which is mixed is the area designs. While the all look good and carry a good atmosphere befitting a Souls game,  some of them feel ... generic, and worse then that, they have no flow to them. Most noteable is the transition from Earthen Peak to the Old Iron Keep. (you take an ELEVATOR, from the top of a broken tower/windmill with nothing around or above it, into an active volcano.) or Aldia's Keep to Dragon's Aerie/Dragon Shrine, which also makes no geographical sence. mInd you, the areas all look nice, but that lack of geographical continuity took a lot away from the game for me, however I belive this issue is the direct result of two choices. 1) Dark Souls II isn't an open world like Dark Souls, its a hub world like Demons Souls (minus the teleporting to the areas to get into them intitally) 2) You can warp via the Bonfires right from the start, unlike in Dark Souls where you where most the way into the game before that unlocked.

Enemy designs are  lack luster, with WAY to many of them being some veriant of 'guy in armor', normal enemys, the tougher mods, even bosses, are, for the most part are just 'a guy in armor', granted, some of them, like the Black Dragon Knights, look awesome, but if your like me you'd be tired of seeing some guy in armor long before the end of the game, and the lore of the game does little to improve things. It has it's bright spots to be sure, and like Dark Souls it is fertal grounds for debate, it's just not up to the bar set with the first game.

Another misstep is PvP, while it 'works' better mechanically, it's actually a worse system. First of all, if your not into PvP, tough,  ether deal with the invasions, or go offline, those are your only options. This is because you can now be invaded as a Hallow as well as human now which can be something of a pain in the ♥♥♥. Another issue is the match making. while I'll freely admit I don't understand how it works, I know it's got to do with your Soul Memory and not your Soul Level, like in Dark Souls and I know a lot of people where complaining about having issues finding some one in PvP because of it, I don't think its been corrected yet ether so just be aware if PvP is your thing. A more personal issue that is likely to REALLY ♥♥♥♥ new players off is how easy it is to stumble into two PvP zones. The Saints Grave and Doors of Pharos are both set in such away that if you don't know those are optional zones, your very likely to wander in and then you'll have to deal with the PvP 'fun' of the Rat Coven, again, if PvP isn't your thing, be aware.

Speaking of the Covens, if your not into PvP, most of them will be worthless to you, if you are, well, only some of them will be if only due to the rewards not being worth the effort (unless your talking about the Blue Sentinals, in which case your better off killing the Coven leader because he drops the armor you get for metting the rediculous requirments to max it out), and even then, there no penalty for abbandoning one for another which kinda makes only being allowed to be in one Coven at a time silly.

Over all, as a Successor to Dark Souls, it fails to live up to the standard set. That said. As a video game devoriced from Dark Souls. It is still a very good, well built game that most every one seeking a challenge and a game that doesn't hold your hand can enjoy if they have the right mind set for it.

reviewText:
Alright. I've heard many people saying this game is a pile of excrements and you really shouldn't play it. These people are mostly Dark Souls 1 Players who can't go with their favorite game being altered a little here and there.
So, before I state my opinion, have some facts about me and the Souls franchise:
-I played both Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2, but I haven't played Demon Souls. I didn't even watch a lot of gameplay or anything.
-I really liked Dark Souls 1, but was scared of the New Game+, so I had 2 NG playthroughs.
-I'm watching a lot of YouTube about DkS1 and 2 (going to abbreviate from now on) and really enjoy it.
-I'm not a noob in DkS1/2, but not even close to some people I've me, and I still use the wiki a lot for locations of keys or certain rings and stuff like that.
-I own a gamepad!

So here's my opinion about DkS2:
YOU SHOULD NOT BUY THE GAME IF YOU
-Don't have a gamepad and are not willing to buy one (!)
-You're looking for a game that leads you through the plot and takes you by the hand" as many people say it
-You can't deal with the sadness and rage that come with every death
-You are a casual gamer and don't have the motivation to finish a game that doesn't make you happy at some point
-You're an idiot who needs a great deal of explanation to understand a game

So
date: if you don't fulfill any of the criteria above: Congratulations
recommended: you might enjoy this game!\nI think it's a pretty good game. It has the possibilities for some really interesting and cool Multiplayer/Co-op fights (that DkS didn't have due to the devils spawn that goes by the name of "Games for Windows Live") and I was so pumped for more lore after finishing DkS that I really enjoyed the main plot itself.\nIf I had to compare this and its prequel
hoursPlayed: i'd say DkS1 is better

which doesn't mean that this is not worth playing though.
I've had a couple of NG playthroughs and 1 NG+ (which really ♥♥♥♥ed me up at some points) and I own all the DLCs and played them (watch out for a large dificulty spike thoughout the Iron Crown one ._. ).

Lemme give you some stats now.

All in all a 6.5/10 game, inferior to DS1 in points of online play, balancing, boss fights etc. Stat scaling is extremely horrible in this game, which renders pure stat builds almost useless. Graphics were a HUGE lie, as they suck hard compared to the promised ones in pre-release status.

reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 is a very good game. At least compared to other action RPGs. However, it's somewhat of a disappointment compared to the first Dark Souls game.

Note: I don't think my Steam statistics are correct (possibly due to playing offline). I've actually played over 100 hours Dark Souls 2.

Also, there is a new 64-bit version of Dark Souls 2 (Scholar of Sin) with improved graphics and new enemy and item placement which supposedly makes the game more difficult. However, if you can get the old version on sale ($20 or less) which now includes all DLCs I would recommend that. For one thing, I've heard that it looks just as good as the new version if you use mods. On the topic of mods, I have had a game-breaking bug with GeDoSaTo, but it seems to be rare.

If you are considering which game to play first I would recommend Dark Souls 1. If you own a PS3 or PS4 I might even recommend playing Demon's Souls and Bloodborne before Dark Souls 2 (although I have only watched, but not played those games).

Dark Souls 2 improves on graphics, performance, and certain elements of the stats system such as attributes and weapon upgrading. It fails in regards to combat, controls, NPCs, and overall atmosphere.

My PC can barely run Skyrim and Dark Souls 1 so I wasn't sure I'd be able to play Dark Souls 2, but on low graphics settings and low resolution Dark Souls 2 runs around 30-40 fps (although it probably looks worse than console with my graphics settings).

Just a side note about frame rate. There is a bug (which still hasn't been fixed after a year of release) which causes weapons to degrade twice as fast at 60 fps compared to 30 fps (PS3/xbox 360 version). I found this awesome whip. Or so I thought....After killing half a dozen enemies it was already more than halfway towards breaking.

It seems that weapons degrade faster even without the bug, but the bug just compounds things. Another change in regards to gameplay is the amount of fall damage you take. If you're used to Dark Souls 1, Demon's Souls, or Bloodborne you're going to die quite a lot due to fall damage.

The weapons upgrade system has improved since Dark Souls 1. After watching someone play Demon's Souls I was saddened to realize how few positives carried over into Dark Souls. However, I believe that Dark Souls 2 has the best upgrade system.

It offers many more options than Dark Souls 1 and yet the process is streamlined and simplified at the same time. There's even an upgrade path that scales off your lowest stat which is useful for people who like playing a character that does a little bit of everything.

In terms of aesthetics (which is somewhat objective) there are things about both games I like, but Dark Souls 2 falls short in terms of atmosphere. There are times where it approaches Dark Souls 1 like No-man's wharf and a certain area in Shaded Woods, but in general things feel a bit off in comparison. It's something almost at an unconscious level which is hard to put into words and something that isn't noticeable until after playing for a period of time.

While not perfect, the attribute system is somewhat improved although it does seem to encourage min/maxing to a certain extent. At the very least, they've done away with the resistance attribute which was worthless in Dark Souls 1.

They've also broken up endurance into two stats which is a good thing overall because it was so overpowered in the first Dark Souls. Instead of making a new stat (and confusingly calling vitality" and renaming vitality from Dark Souls 1 as "vigor") they should have made endurance only have a minor affect on equipment load and instead made strength have more of an effect on equp load.

The reason why I make this suggestion about strength is that weapons are still unbalanced in Dark Souls 2. The heaviest weapons are almost never the best choice due to the game mechanics and stats system. They're still viable
date:
but nowhere near optimal. It's something I might do after my 1st or 2nd playthrough after I've gotten good at the game.

Another change which I consider an improvement is how they do rings and enchanted items. There are many more pieces of armor that have some sort of special enchanment which makes getting new loot more enjoyable.

While I haven't had a chance to thoroughly test out the magic system
recommended: it does seem to be more balanced compared to the first game. At the very least
hoursPlayed: there are many more options including hexes which is sort of a dark magic. Great for a necromancer roleplay.\n\nRings are also more balanced. Instead of having 2 ring slots and a few very powerful rings
voteText: there's 4 rings slots and less powerful rings. Some rings have a more powerful variant which you can find much later in the game which gives you a feeling of progression rather than the first Dark Souls where you can get the most powerful rings in the first half of the game.\n\nThere has been a huge debate over the difficulty in Dark Souls 2. Some say it's easier than the first and others who say it's as hard (if not harder) than the first. I'm one of the people who feel that it was at least as hard as the first. While there were cheap things in regards to difficulty with both games
helpfulPercent: I feel like the difficulty overall was handled better in the first Dark Souls.\n\nMy biggest annoyance with the first game were the platforming challenges. I don't necessarily mean jumping
votesHelpful: but rather dying due to fall damage. Despite what I said earlier about fall damage being worse in Dark Souls 2
votesTotal: there were a lot of areas where falling meant instant death. Sometimes the fall was provoked by enemies in the area and other times it was purely environmental.\n\nIn Dark Souls 2
votesFunny: the biggest issue with difficulty was the enemies themselves. First of all
commentsCount: there were often too many of them which led to a lot of kiting and hit and run tactics. Or relying too much on ranged attacks. Don't get me wrong
column16: there were many occasions in Dark Souls 1 where I was overwhelmed by enemies
column17: but with that game it always felt more manageable.\n\nPart of that was due to how poise worked and the enemies' AI. Because of the changes to poise
column18: it's much easier to get stunlocked in Dark Souls 2 even if you're wearing reasonably heavy armor.\n\nThe other thing is that Dark Souls 2 enemies have the ability to track you with their attacks so that it much more difficult to gain a tactical edge without retreating. I admit that it was too easy to backstab enemies in the first Dark Souls
column19: but this "fix" seems lazy. It might have been better to eliminate backstabs altogether than this which just feels unfair.\n\nThe NPCs in Dark Souls 2 were another big disappointment. They just seem kind of dull in comparison to the first game. I'm not sure if this was intentional as a way of showing the hollowing process
column20: but it didn't work for me. In Dark Souls 1 the NPCs were full of life. Even the despicable ones who would screw you over were preferable to the bland ones in Dark Souls 2. Even Lucatiel
column21: my favorite NPC from Dark Souls 2 is kind of meh.\n\nAll in all
column22: the gameplay changes are a mixed bag. It really depends on who you talk to
column23: but for me there were some improvements and some steps backwards. I've heard mixed things about PvP in terms of which game is better
column24: but I haven't tried it myself.\n\nThe issue that seems to be the most common source of disappointment is that Dark Souls 2 feels like it's missing its soul (please excuse the pun). I've heard many reasons people give for disliking Dark Souls 2 and many of them seem very nitpicky. While gameplay is probably my biggest disappointement
column25: I feel the issue which affects most people is that Dark Souls 2 is missing the very essence which makes Dark Souls a "souls game". Which is one of the main reasons that I'd recommend Demon's Souls and Bloodborne (both made by the developer as Dark Souls) over Dark Souls 2 despite having not played either of them."

reviewText:
Its a very good game. It tests your patience and tactics, and continuously eats em up. Its up to the player on how he will finish his enemies, but rewards and satisfaction awaits on the other side.

This game is not as difficult as many make it out to be. As long as you have a strategy to take down enemies and can learn to parry, roll, and block attacks with a shield, you should be fine. An important thing to note is that if you are a human and die, you become a hollow (a zombie-esque creature). Not only does that start to shrink your maximum health, but you are no longer be able to summon phantoms to aid you in battle, so becuareful with that.

PS: DON'T touch the red summon signs. I'm warning you right now.

Overall, an amazing game with really good lore attached to it. If you get the chance to play this game, listen to the lore and you will be amazed.

reviewText:
There is nothing to say - absolute masterpiece in Action/RPG genre.

Well actually things I personally didnt like, comparing to DS1:
1) More linear level design - much less alternative routes, ability to teleport between bonfires from start of the game=>locations almost not connected to each other). Remember Depths, Blighttown and Sen's Fortress from original DS - ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mazes

2) Bosses - like more than half of them are knights, yes - well designed, but fights with them too monotonous.

3)And maybe soundtrack not so memorable with exceptions of Majula, Vendrick's theme, Nashandra, Credits music and 2 or 3 bosses.

But the rest is at the same high level and even better. Gorgeus Atmosphere, level design. Difficult and deep lore. Interface - much more convenient to use. PvP and Jolly Cooperation" - even more fun and addictive.

9/10"

reviewText:
This is the best action role-playing game since Dark Souls.

What I LikedEasy to learn, hard to master: Weapons can attack one-handed or two-handed, right-handed or left-handed, quickly or forcefully, and they have special attacks after running or rolling. Attack combos are never more than two button presses. Shields, bows, and catalysts work like weapons, but block, shoot, or cast instead of attacking. Regardless of what you wield, you can run, jump, roll, and use items. That's pretty much it; Dark Souls 2's actions are simple and intuitive. However, using them effectively requires much more attention than is needed in far more complicated games. For example, in Tekken 6, once a long combo is started, muscle memory can do all the work for a good five seconds. In Dark Souls 2, every single action must be carefully chosen, timed, and placed.

Ernest Hemingway: If a writer of prose knows enough of what he is writing about he may omit things that he knows and the reader
date: if the writer is writing truly enough
recommended: will have a feeling of those things as strongly as though the writer had stated them." Dark Souls 2 applies this idea to its story and setting
hoursPlayed: and the result is quite compelling. Even the significance of the final boss is something you probably won't immediately understand—but there is at least one good explanation for that and for just about everything else in the narrative. You can find that explanation if you take the time to find all the clues and put them together. (And if you don't care to do so
voteText: there are plenty of good lore videos on YouTube to do it for you.)\n\nMassive replay value: There are countless possible variations for player characters
helpfulPercent: both aesthetic and mechanical. The eight classes are each tailored to a different combat style
votesHelpful: yet even they don't represent every viable style (e.g. pyromancy and hexing don't have dedicated classes). It may be illustrative to note that of the 650 hours I've spent on this game so far
votesTotal: the most I've spent on one character has been 150 hours.\n\nOriginality: Feel free to design your character as the typical JRPG protagonist (long-haired
votesFunny: pale-skinned
commentsCount: improbably young)... You will spend much of your first playthrough as the hideous green walking corpse of that character. Dark Souls 2 defies many tropes of both Western and Japanese RPGs (perhaps because it's a Japanese take on Western fantasy). It's not entirely a Darker and Edgier[tvtropes.org] Deconstructor Fleet[tvtropes.org]

column17: it intermixes strongly contrasting elements—beauty and ugliness
column18: light and dark
column19: benevolence and malice—in a way that makes these extremes more striking when encountered.\n\nWell-balanced items: There are heated discussions in the Souls community about this or that overpowered weapon

Dark Souls 2's logarithmic power curve makes it so even someone who's permanently lost half their souls is only at a small disadvantage against someone who's permanently lost none. Also

Yes, there is a version of this game with DirectX 11 coming out, and yes it's supposed to be superior to this version. edit: it also includes all the DLC.
Should that stop you from buying this version? Definitely NOT.

Dark Souls 2 is a refreshing change of pace from most games that are typically being released (with the exception of a few games, ex. Wasteland 2, I also recommend that game!) with the idea of a combat heavy RPG.

What makes this game different than the rest? I would personally have to say it's the detail and variety that goes into everything, like the lore, there are so many hints about some whatever scattered around in item descriptions, dialouge, and even the area you are in. reviewText:
This is a fun and enjoyable game, with more content, fun filled pvp combat and a vast improvement over the original that is plagued by some problems and technical issues that could make you love it or hate it.

A great improvement over the original game, I really do enjoy this game very much in fact so much I've spent 300+  hours on it in the console version of the game that I had to rebuy the pc version to experience all over again.
I was  disappointed by some of the things  because of the fact that its still felt like a port and not really a huge graphical improvement that I thought it would be/have. Bad controls on keyboard and mouse, and missing alot of the lightning and features I wished was included which was talked about in videos. Also hackers are annoying and yeah they still exist when ya kill them and get  millions souls outta nowhere as a new char and that can really screw up YOUR game because of soul memory system.. I had to go through some trouble on getting my  controller to work well. Vac bans is useful but still useless at the same time,

The game starts you off in the middle of nowhere just to venture into the hut of the witches to understand your path, the game feels very branched out in the beginning where you can go and have to go and what you can explore then it gets very limited on what you can do once you reach close to the end it just starts being limited in where you have to go. There are however many things you can find and discover, weapons to upgrade, souls to fight, people to kill.
Once you beat the game new game + changes the challenge up again by adding new foes and new enemies thus getting harder. This time around if you run outta enemies you can summon them using bonfire aesthetics.

Other than that,  the game this time is a huge improvement over   the original due to what is being offered which is  more content, more covenants, weapons , and very much of the very similar gameplay that you are used to. The soul memory systemt his time stops the twinks from happening so you won't encounter players that are OP and twinked out that will completely rip you apart.

This is a fun game for those with the acquired taste, You'll die, have your ego crushed on by a steamroller while being axed by a gnome but you will still press on. however the story is still weak and the at least there was an attempt at it, Also there were videos of the game looking great with lighting and the graphics that was shown from the beta version which was taken out of this game making it look uglier than it's supposed to be, there are tons of videos about it online and its very upsetting this was done but at the end of the day dark souls II is what it is, a challenging game that is focused on pvping other players down and having fun.

+ Game is harder, but only because they throw alot of enemies at you otherwise...
+ New content, LOTS of new content
+ Combat feels more fun
+ New game plus after beating the game actually includes more unexpected mobs, and becomes harder, its actually a ng+!
+ covenants that are useful and categorized well, Pve/pvp/pve invasion/pve helping/pvp evil etc.
+ Good larger open areas gorgeous views in certain areas.
+ Fps is smooth game runs smooth doesn't look the best but smooth is good
+ Finally runs well on the pc due to the support. Especially the display
+ Pvping/combat is so much fun. I love to gank and fight legit players
+ Using Steam vac bans, not the best way to ban people but better than nothing.
+ Good variety of weapons to mess with, upgrade and stat up.
+ Mod it up! but you'll have to play offline just in case because of vac just in case.

- Story still weak
- Its hard to know if playing online will get you banned or not due to modding, so do it offline
- Expected better quality graphics and shadings, things that was shown beta phase didn't make it they took it out, Alot were ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off. You've been gearboxed.
- Having some connection problems, this is due to soul memory matchups
- Some fight mechanic needs rebalancing
- Bosses are not as memorable as dark souls
- Game need to be made by pc for once so we can experience true quality, I shouldn't have to mod my game to make it look amazing
- Even though keyboard and mouse is cutomizable I cannot find it likeable for this game best to use controller, its still horrible!
- Enemies AI are still stupid, bosses are unmemorable
- Cheaters really ruin the pvp experience


Overall - I still recommend this game for what it is and what it offers, I looked past the incredible amount of negativity i've experienced because I really do love this series. I really do hope capcom really put thier act together for the next game. The pc version had me clocked in less hours than the console versions due to cheaters and because I burned myself out.

reviewText:
Its the cynical by-the-numbers sequel we were all secretly expecting. Dark Souls 1 is the better game in most aspects, but DKS2 triumphs in a couple places.

1, the new game+ has seen a lot of hard work and theres chunks of content you cant even see until youve beat the game several times.
2, secrets are way more prominent, be they the new super-hidden false walls or inaccessable parts of old areas you can revisit.
3, there was a revamped lighting system planned in development, where you could forego your off-hand to carry a torch and illuminate dark areas. The lighting plan was more or less ruined by release, but theres still a good 2 or 3 levels where a torch is viable, and those levels tend to be pretty awesome (except for shrine of amana, for unrelated reasons).
4, dks2 is a better PC port than dark souls, with steamworks instead of GFWL, passable keyboard controls and a less insulting options menu.

Otherwise, you get more for less by just getting the first game. Lore, combat, exploration, enemy variety, level design, bosses and multiplayer; whatever 2 actually improves upon, it simultaneously breaks so much that it may as well have not bothered.

If you loved dks1 and just want more dark souls, this product more or less performs as advertised.

reviewText:
Well, this was expected wasn't it!

To preface this, I am playing this with Keyboard and Mouse, and it is not advised to read this if you're not okay with minor spoilers (they're tagged as spoilers, so just don't hover of them), as they're hard to avoid. Dark Souls 2 is one of the games I've enjoyed the most, I am about to wrap my first playthrough up as I enter the end game, spending nearly 50 hours on it already.

In comparison to Dark Souls 1, this game does a lot of things right, and a few things wrong.

This review consists of four headers, the things that went wrong, the things that went good, the things that I do not have a strong opinion of and the conclusion.


Things gone wrong

Keyboard and Mouse default configuration
Whoever designed the default settings for keyboard and mouse wasn't doing it right - they're just nonsensical and dumb. I had to readjust a lot of keys, and the keybinding system is mediocre, but I managed to find settings to my pleasing. And once set right, the experience was smooth.

Traps
There are a few ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized traps that you just can't see coming, like boulders, monsters suddenly breaking walls, and breaking floors that lead to oblivion.
Although these things are part of the game, I feel like, especially when dying to them, these things should have been introduced differently, in perhaps a more forgiving away. As it's not a thrill introduced to you, it's just plain bull.

Introduction Cinematic, and entirety of the plot
The plot feels edgy to me, you're intructed to do something, but are never told why -- except for That you really don't know why you're doing this". The concept is silly
date: and you're really only doing this for a silly item. I'm sure there's more to it
recommended: but the essense of the plot really rolls around to finding a certain item
hoursPlayed: so you can use it to open doors.\n\nI really liked the plot in Dark Souls 1
voteText:
Dark Souls 2 did not give this feeling to me.

NPCs
The NPCs in Majula just don't give me the feeling that they're really alive. They remain in the same position and don't do much else. Their dialogue is mostly the same and they don't change a lot.

Leading me onto one of the most annoying NPCs. ->
The Green Maiden
I can practically dream her dialogue

reviewText:
There is a great game trying to happen here but its marred by bad design choices and poor experties by Fromsoft. the overall feel of it is lacking, no real plot what so ever, the best i can come up with is your in drangliek because you are, why are you killing these bosses and progressing through the game, because its the only thing to do, who are these bosses the answer is mostly some dude in a suit of armour or a monster.

The coding is screwed to the extreme, there is no way this is a lead platform when changing the fps to 60 changes how enemies move or attack, an example is alonne knights or the dog things from the gutter with their 360 bite attack which hits you halfway throught he animation or maybe the spider zombies in brightstone cove which can hit you just as you kill them.

The stats have been changed alot and for the worse. The names why is my equip load called vitality but my health is vigor? In fact why did they split the gain of weight limit and stamina gain into 2 diffrent stats? Iframes from rolling must now be bought via adaptability, and you will be rolling because you wont use a sheild for 70% of the game as only about few are worth actualy using not that turtling behind a sheild would have been usefull as there is a guardbreak move to stop that.

Now the locations are good looking but not in anyway coherent, travel through a poisen area up a tower then take a lift to a castle on a lake of lava, where did this lift take me why is there lava above a tower. The locations may look cool the best one is drangliek castle after you go through the shrine of winter, the feel and atmosphere is great. But others are small rooms or single areas which just require backtracking or frustrating paths.

The bosses are okay and lets leave it at that becuase the developer must have been told capra, O and S and four kings from Dark Souls 1 were the hardest boss battles so to make the bosses harder in this game we must add more of them prime example is gargs in belfry luna, dark souls 1 = 2 gargoyles and the second one spawns with half health dark souls 2 = 5 gargoyles all with full hp and then the total hp reaches a certian point more spawn mostly when you have almost killed one another will join. Or the prime spam boss Dear Duke's Freyja, the most dangerous things in the boss room are the small spiders i could kill the big one in my sleep its the small ones which are most dangerous.

Soul memory i actualy like the idea of and how its implimented, would i like an option to swith between soul memory and soul level connectivity yes but its not that bad. The signs are a great idea as well small signs for short summon times or if the boss has been killed and big for longer times and if the boss is unkilled.

AH but how are the builds you think, well they are rubbish strength is great fun as the lowest defence is strike for most enemies, dex is nerfed doubly by only getting half the paramater bonuses that strength does and durability being so small its horrible to play with some weapons. And most people who have played Fromsoft's games know they have a hardon for magic especialy dark magic and hasn't nerfed it at all since the game came out, also dont bother with faith as they ruined that build with the second dlc.

DLC meh didnt try it the main game is sub par so its most likely subpar aswell, from what i have seen and heard is more gangs of enemies swaming the players, reusing bosses from the main campaign as literal copy pastes with pallet swapping from some.

Overall a 5 or a 6 out of 10 worth getting if you want it but otherwise dont bother get dark souls 1 its better in every aspect, also lost izlith is better then some areas in dark souls 2 and they didnt finish lost izlith.

reviewText:
It’s quite safe to say that Dark Souls 2 is one of the more polarizing games in the franchise. Back when it first came out, people flung their poo at it and called it a disappointment compared to the previous game and while most people now still do, I have to admit that I was among them at first. I thought that Dark Souls 2 had tried too hard to copy its predecessor, resulting in a fanservice-riddled mess of a game that couldn’t decide whether or not it wanted to be a worthwhile addition to the franchise or a shameless rehash of what we’ve already been through. Thankfully, Dark Souls 2 is mostly the former.

Bad news first: This game is indeed sprinkled with shameless fanservice. As an example, you will run into Ornstein as an early boss with no real justification as to why he’s there and you’ll get the same weapon from his soul that you did from the last game. There’s also the Great Lightning Spear miracle which directly references the “grossly incandescent” line that the internet loves so much in its description.

The worst part about this game is probably how it, like every other game in the franchise, gets off on killing you as much as possible. There will be a number of occasions where you’ll run into another bonfire not far away from a boss, but there is still a gauntlet of enemies you’ll need to get through in order to actually reach the boss which will likely cost you some healing items and durability on your equipment.

Speaking of durability, all of your weapons seem to be made out of butter in this game. Standard weapons like the Broadsword might last you through an area or two, whereas the more fragile weapons like the Malformed Skull won’t even last you through a single boss fight. There was also a bug that originated in the PC version where your hitboxes were tied to your framerate, and the PC versions had a framerate of 60 over the 360/PS3’s 30, so every weapon you swung broke twice as fast. This was fixed after the Scholar of the First Sin remake came out... eleven months after the PC version was released.

Design in general is lacking. Enemies don’t have as much variation as they did in the previous game. A fair few of them are humans with regular weapons and some of them are humans with variations on what weapons and armour they have and in varying sizes. Bosses are also mostly large armoured humanoids with greatswords and don’t show much variance there and if we’re including DLC, then in Crown of the Old Iron King, you’ll run into a reskinned Smelter Demon that now creates an AoE explosion when it powers up its core and can now slow down its attack animations to throw off your roll timing. There’s also the Crown of the Ivory King DLC where you’ll run into one new boss, then later on you’ll encounter the same boss again, but you’ll have to fight two of them at once and they have a fun new self-buff ability when one of them dies. They’re accessed through what has to be the most tedious area in the whole game and possibly video gaming history, the Frigid Outskirts. It takes at least five minutes to rush through the area and you’ll have horses shooting lightning up your rear end the whole time. There’s no bonfire any closer to the boss fog, either.

There are also a few strange design decisions thrown in, such as a weird, pulsating bloodstain overlay texture appearing on your screen during every pre-boss fight cutscene. There’s no good reason to include this. I can see the giant armoured humanoid with a greatsword in the cutscene, thank you. It’s an eyesore and adds nothing positive to the game and if there were no fog walls mid-stage, there would be absolutely no possible reason to include this.

Now, the good news. There are a handful of good game design decisions that make Dark Souls 2 a more player-friendly experience. For starters, you no longer have to venture into the seventh circle of Hell to get to a blacksmith just to ascend one weapon to Fire or something, then upgrade the next four levels later on at a bonfire but only if you have a certain key item like you had to in the previous game. As soon as you find the Dull Ember, you take it to one single blacksmith and he will handle every single one of your weapon’s infusions. He can also upgrade your items just the same as the one in Majula can. You can also swap between weapon infusions and your weapon will retain its upgrade level, instead of having to downgrade your weapon to its +10 standard upgrade path then infuse it into its new upgrade path and wasting all of those upgrade items.

For those who find the game too hard, you have the option of using a Ring of Life Protection to prevent yourself from losing your humanity and your souls at the cost of the ring breaking. Unlike the Ring of Sacrifice in Dark Souls 1 and 3 which disappear after use, these rings can be repaired for a few thousand souls each and are very useful for those who either wish to make the PvE easier, or hosts of PvP worlds who do not wish to use their more valuable human effigies should they die. Conversely, there’s the Company of Champions covenant which you can join if you feel like the game is too easy. Joining this covenant will disable your ability to summon phantoms into your world for co-op, make enemies dish out and take more damage and your reward for this is the occasional Awestone drop, which can be traded for a few unique rewards, including a ring which increases your bare fist damage by a lot, making it a very feasible weapon for the whole game. There is also no penalty for abandoning any of the covenants.

For those who prefer to play their games in co-op, you’ll be pleased to know that this is easily the best implementation of it that the series has ever had. In the previous two games, you had no direct method of control for who saw your summon sign. Here, a new item called the Name-engraved Ring allows you to pick between ten different gods to favour, then while the ring is on, only people who have also picked that same god can see your summon sign and receive yours. I live in Australia and I have been able to connect to people who live in the US and Canada and it's never taken longer than twenty seconds, compared to Dark Souls which has taken half an hour and Bloodborne, where a connection couldn't be established after a full hour.

While this one may be subjective, I feel that it’s worth mentioning that there is also a noticeable degree of absurdity in this game that sits quite well with me. If I can find a weapon in the game that’s both practical and aesthetically pleasing, I’ll use it. There’s the top half of a dragon’s skull, a giant melted lump of iron and a straight up beam sword that all have their uses depending on what you want to build, plus they’re fun to use, very creatively designed and balanced well.

While the Souls games have been generally renowned for their ability to be the video gaming equivalent of throwing cupcakes at a wall to knock it over until you eventually do which people seem to perceive as “difficult, but fair”, Dark Souls 2 does have enough good points to contrast against its flaws to the point that it gets a content single thumb up from me, rather than two enthusiastic thumbs up. There are still problems with it, but it’s absolutely serviceable as a video game and while I wouldn’t recommend picking it up at full price, waiting for a decent sale will at least soften the blow if you find it disappointing at all. It may leave a bad taste in your mouth at first with its shoddy art and enemy design, but it’s worth trudging through in the end for the gameplay, weapons and even co-op.

reviewText:
One of the biggest let down in a game I have ever bought. I was so ready to love it, so ready to be immeresed in a story that would enthrall me like those games from which it came. But...something must have happened in its developement.

There are many reasons this is. Going through 2 loading screens to level up, levels that look beautiful but are basically a hallway with a for in it, varrying levels of quality, puzzling map design (go up elevater of tower that is nowhere near volcano or mountain, appear in a castle on top of a castle), pvp got gutted, it feels.....hollow.

There is no fear, there is no attachment, there is no love like I had with the others. It isn't a bad game, but it isn't a great game. It isn't a game I would sink tons of hours into. This is a dumbed down version of its brothers. It could have been so much more, it had potential, but it stumbled. I have never felt sad about a game falling short before, but anger or indeference. I felt sad for this game, I felt sad for what this could have been.

reviewText:
Please, take notice that if you're buying this game now, you'll be buying an OLD VERSION of it, as the newer version with all the new DLC's in it will be released in 4 months with extra content. The new version will split the community in two parts which will lead the the end of DaS2 Online play.
If you're buying this game now, you'll have to spend 50€ for the next-gen version. More information coming from FromSoft end of this month. Game is good, but wait for the next gen one to come out.

PRO's:
- Exciting game, easy to coop if you start playing at the same time. ( Due to the addition of the Name engraved ring )
- Has a high skill curve PvE wise, some mobs are weak to x weapon, you'll have to adapt yourself to the game making it a challenging game.
- Hours of fun, your first playtrough should take 30 - 50 Hours And then there's NG+ Which adds even more content.
- Dlc's are good.
- Some references to DS1 if you already played the first one.
- You get rewarded if you finish the game without dying or resting at a bonfire.


CON's:
- Not much lore, but they're fixing it with Scholar of the first Sin.
- PvP is repetitive in high SM as you'll be facing the same people using the same meta ( Current meta being chaos katana, havel, jester, etc. )
- Some bosses / Invaders have ♥♥♥♥ AI and will just fall to their dead if you know how to do it. ( Which does offer speedrun routes! )
- Bad servers, making cooperation & PvP laggy.
- You'll have to buy a controller, or else you won't be able to guard break, leap attack or make a correct use of all the small things the controls have to offer. ( This game is a port from Xbox, an xbox controller is recommended )
- Farming will be necessary if you want to try out everything.

reviewText: Dark Souls 2 is good, but has a lot of flaws that should have been addressed when everything was being designed. There's so much variety in gameplay that its hard to get bored of it. I have it on console where I started gaming and decided that it was good enough to get again on PC and I'll be getting it again, having to start over because of DX11, but its worth it. Its a shame you can't continue your previous saves because of Scholar of First Sin coming out, but they are going to be entirely different games (hopefully), so it shouldn't matter nearly as much. My biggest complaint is the fact that the game offers so many weapons that end up being useless in comparison to the top tier weapons. All the weapon classes and playstyles have their place, but can be severly imbalanced. One of the strongest weapons in game is a giant purple pop sickle (Crypt Black Sword) and can drop you extremely quick where as some of the more intriguing weapons (IMO) like the Murakumo, Scythes and Halberds aren't as powerful. If there was a top tier weapon of every weapon class, then I think the game would be much more balanced.\n\nOh yeah, if you invade, be prepared to get ganked.

reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 is pretty cool, I guess. Note that I do not have the season pass or any of the DLC because it's more money than I'm willing to spend on a single video game, no matter how much I actually like it.

Please don't tell people how I live.

Dark Souls 2 is a sequel to Dark souls which is a successor to Demon's Souls, which in turn is a spiritual successor to Kings Field. I'm sure if we dig deep enough we can fit Ultima in there somewhere.

You play as a Zombie. I mean Undead. With your soul slowly tearing itself away from you and your memory fading, you travel to the land of Drangleic, a land of knights and kings and giant men who probably look good in a speedo. After falling into a lake, I think, you end up marching your corpse up into a little cabin where a few old ladies and their maid live. These old ladies call you a chump, slap some complexion into your face, and send you on your merry way to exhaust all NPC dialogue and appraise every single item you come across for that sweet sweet flavor text so you can sort of maybe kind of figure out what happened to the kingdom. Maybe.

Dark Souls 2 plays much like Dark Souls, where you travel far and wide and kill everything that stands in your way. Or kill them again, I'm not entirely certain on how the undead part works. Attack and defense are mapped to your shoulder buttons, or your mouse clicks if you're brave or a hairy man living in a box behind the local Coop like me. Combat consists of you waiting for an opening to shove your boot so far up some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s brown hole that they taste leather and iron. Your reward for ending someones guard or monster career three days from retirement is their souls. Brutal.

Souls work like experience and currency, with it you can buy new items and even buff up your character so he can pretend he goes to the undead gym and do undead bench presses instead of murdering other undead in cold blood and sucking the life force out of them you awful awful monster. That's not to say your victims won't put up a fight. Outside of magic, monsters, and melee, you will have to deal with traps and even other players. These players are called jerks and should leave me alone I'm trying to get to the next boss, go bother someone who isn't trying to take the giant medusa lady atop a windmill on a date.

Jerk.

But lets talk about the difficulty, one of the Souls' series main features. A lot of reviewers and journalists called this game impossible. These people also still eat their own boogers. Ha. Ha. Ha. Ha. Ha. Ha. Ha.
Dark Souls 2 is a game about experience, the more you know, the better you do. If you take it slow and examine your surroundings, chances are you won't get smacked in the face by a trap. Trap as in something that kills you, not trap as in the kind of stripper you hope your friends hire for you as a goof during your birthday party and you go Haha

your secret is safe with me.

reviewText:
This time around From Software did a decent job porting the game to the PC graphically speaking, with the game running much more smoothly compared to their consoles counterpart. Unfortunately in other areas, such as control scheme, the problems found in Dark Souls I is still present here. GUI menus are still labeled with XBOX controller layout. And whichever employee came up with the bright idea that mouseclick and doubleclick should be bound to two different commands in combat should be fired. Oh you clicked the mouse button a nanosecond too fast? I am sure you meant to do strong attack instead of a combo so here, have a strong attack! HAHA! Oh you want to unbind the doubleclick command so you won't make this mistake anymore? Well, that means when you doubleclick, you just want to stand there doing nothing while that monster wails at you, right? Sure, we can do that! HAHAHA! Oh, now you want to bind both mouseclick and doubleclick to light attack so you can pull a simple combo without throwing your mouse at the wall in frustration? HAHA NO YOU CAN'T DO THAT!

These control scheme problems are easily fixed by plugging a gamepad to your PC so I hope you have one! Otherwise, have fun with all the silly control scheme issues the game have. Shame because the game itself is excellent provided you have a gamepad, but it is nigh unplayable using a keyboard and mouse.

tl;dr:
Excellent game provided you have a gamepad for your PC, annoying Chuck-the-mouse-at-the-wall-and-headbutt-the-keyboard-in-frustration problems with GUI and control schemes without one.

reviewText:
Punishing,  Unforgiving yet so Addictive !
Oh, Dark Souls 2 where do I begin. Having spend more than 1000 hours from earlier titles by FromSoftware such as the Tenchu series, Demon souls, Dark souls and now Dark souls 2. I am happy to annouce that Dark souls 2 definitely lives up to the hype shown in last year's E3 as well as all the trailers lurking around the internet and our anticipation buidling up for the april pc release.

One of the biggest difference between the console version and the Pc version is that this time around, FromSoft constructed the PC version from ground up instead of porting it over which means that the graphics can be adjusted depending on the computer spec and that the experience is further enhanced by 60fps running constantly on most pcs. Textures is also much more detailed than dark souls 1 thanks for the improved game engine. Furthermore, the features provided by convenants and items all work well and match making seem to work constantly without the need to idle in the same location just to wait for an opponent.

The unique match making mechanic found in dark souls 2 is also different to the first game and instead of using soul levels as a measure of player strength, the game uses soul memory (SM) so that this way it can be more balanced in both pve and pvp.

The Story
Once again, player takes on the role of a nameless hero who became the bearer of curse and arrived in the plagued and dying land of Drangleic. Only by acquiring powerful souls of the ancient, the player will be able to confront the King and the Queen which will inturn free the hero from said curse. On the surface, dark souls 2 does not provide you with 'up your face' insight in what is going on around you as well as the lore and the background. However, smart players will soon find that all the information you seek will be found by talking to npcs scattered around the world as well as reading the description of every items found in the game. This provide enough solid fact to construct an excellent rpg and enough myths left for players to interpret.

Gameplay
First of all, I recommend players to have a game pad in order to play this game because keyboard and mouse control is awkward and often involve pressing keys located faraway from each other or unusual for video games. In terms of control I would say that the core mechanics is still solid and similar to the first game with minor improvements made but that is actually a good thing for veteran players and new players alike because it is intuitive in ways of switching weapons/shields and tools or spells. You only need to press the matched direction button on D-pad to allow switch of equipments. Dark souls 2 also introduced a equipment durability bar even thought it also existed in the first game. In dark souls 2 banging equipments against the wall will repel you and at the same time it will damage your equipment getting it low will be risky and lower its efficiency, breaking it will rendering it useless and require souls to be repaired by a black smith. Similarly, using heavy attack has also proven to degrade equipment at a fast pace.

Graphics
Before you go on and say anything, I know that buying a souls game for its graphics is not what the developer wanted us to do and im not saying dark souls 2 graphics is bad. In fact, it is great. Dark souls 2 features some of the most amazing visuals I have seen in recent years. From the mountain peak of Dragon Aerie to the land scape of Drangleic Castle and to the decaying undead crypt, it shows historical traits of traditional medieval fantasy perfectly and authentically portrayed in a video game. In addition to the graphic, the music is also really well composed from the intense and dangerous boss fight sound track to the grand, majestical and beautifully orchestrated music of a royal palace, the game really mixed and blended two features really well which will often get you pump and feel the sense of achievement after defeating the seemingly unbeatable bosses. Moreover, Dark souls 2 also features original voices given to the npcs of the game from the honorable knight of Mirrah to the traveller of Jugo as well as the lowly merchant of Volgen the game is really trying to create one hell of a unique and immersive experience for the player at every turn.

Difficulty
FromSoftware is notorious for creating difficult games that torment players and punishing them for little mistakes at the most important moment. There has also been rumours that Dark souls 2 is easier than Dark souls 1 and many features were dumbed down to make it more accessible to new players. In some way it is. However, what dark souls 2 provide with players is more freedom in what they want to do. For example if someone finds the game too easy or not challenging enough, they can use an item called 'Bonfire Ascetic' to increase the damage and the health of the enemies at the same time it reduces the amount of damage dealt by the player and if that is not enough, you can burn Bonfire Ascetics 8 times to cap the difficulty. If you wanna be even more hardcore you can also join the convenant of champions which will add another layer of difficulty and disable the co-op function to make the game solo only.

Verdict
Overall, I think that darksouls 2 is the best game of 2014 with amazing production value, replayability and accessbility. However, it could also be one of those game that only caters to a certain crowd of gamers.

Finally, If you enjoyed the first game, you will enjoy this game even more and if you enjoy S&M you will love this game

10/10

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is from someone who has not played the original Dark Souls.

This game is hard, very hard. Is it the hardest? No. Definitively not. But it is hard. Death will be common. But if you keep powering through, you will get better, and then it really gets fun. The weapons in this game allow almost, I repeat, ALMOST   any weapon viable, the exceptions being mostly joke weapons and the pickaxe. Casting is useful in both PvE, and PvP. Sadly, most PvP matches end up with you fighting the same weapon over and over again *cough* Chaos Blade *cough*. Also, the armor in this game lets you have a lot of freedom with how you want your character to look. I've personally seen many cosplays in-game, while making a few myself. I've seen characters ranging from Zero from the Mega Man franchise to The Miner from Risk of Rain. Personally, with the amount of hours I've put into this game, I find PvE not that difficult or interesting, what holds me to this this game it the PvP. Now the PvP is flawed, definitely. Laggy players end up one-shotting you with magic or a backstab, backstabphishers are everywhere, and hackers run rampant. Hackers in general are a major problem. Its very simple to do it, and you can really get screwed by them. Firsthand, I have seen plenty of hackers, I've seen infinite health hackers, casters that can cast huge AoE hacks impossibly fast, and, my personal favorite, a person who invaded me, backstabbed me into an area (since backstabs teleport you to where it connected on their end) where I couldn't kill myself, and proceeded to enter the safe haven Majula, which is not invade-able, and has the only merchant that sells you healing items and never runs out of stock and a merchant that sell you an infinite supply of most upgrade materials. Killing other players' NPCs is also not possible legitimately. Even after all that, I still love this game. Its probably in my top 3 favorite games. Just know what can happen. Also,please use a controller when you play this game, the keyboard controllers really bad, in my opinion. Also, just want to say this at the end, make sure you can run this game. Just saying. Don't be like me, the player who doesn't have a good enough graphics card, and plays the game without being able to see particles, including, but not limited to, summon signs, bloodstains, and all casts, excluding crystal magic. If you're asking how I play the game, most casts have a drop shadow under them, so I use that to my advantage. Still have no idea when hexes are happening, unless I see them cast it, since most of those don't have drop shadows. Still I play this game almost religiously with this problem.

If you love a good challenge, and you have hours you want to spend, buy this game.

reviewText: A very fun and challenging game,most of the time if you die it is completely your fault,the other part is gravity. The game has a very well timed system of attacking,blocking,and/or rolling. Storywise unless you are willing to dig into the lore in the items and the world itself you will find it lacking. The enemies and world design are great in this game and the boss fights are fun and challenging. A new player will have a bit more difficulty then the experienced player,but even the experienced player messes up and can die. The PvP in this game is my one quarrel with this game,it is very unbalanced and needs work especially the arena,I promise you that most of the time it takes me forever to find someone to play with,and even when you do connect to someone it is usually a very cheap build that doesn't take very long to make while someone else tries to make a fun build that takes forever that will only be shot down online. Otherwise very great game that I play pretty regularly. 9/10

reviewText:
As much as I want, I can't recommend this game on its own.
After playing Dark Souls: Prepare to die edition, Dark Souls II felt incredibly stiff and slow. It wasn't like adjusting to a new, better game but to an older version with better grafics. I expected much and most of my expectations weren't satisfied. The story and the enemies are sure great, but it just doesn't feel like Dark Souls anymore.
The best comparrison is the fight against the boss Old Dragonslayer, who's clearly based on a boss in Dark Souls I. There he was a real challenge, fast, agile and powerful, while in DS II he is slow and predictable.

I don't want to say that you shouldn't play DS II at all, but the 32-bit version isn't worth your money, especially as you have to buy the DLC's seperatly from the game. Try Dark Souls II: Scholar of the first sin for the better gaming experience.

reviewText:
While sticking to it roots Dark Souls 2 is a phenomenal sequel. Combat is addictive, the dungeon crawling is addictive; and the aspect of if you can't beat a certain boss, go to a different area and level up and gain new items and then return to the boss that once brought you such great misfortune. I'll simplify it this way

Pros:
It's still a souls game +
PC controls are much more adequate than the last +
Storyline is very intriguing +
No class is better than the rest (Balanced) +

Cons:
Game feels linear late game (Compared to DS1) -
Hitboxes go wonky once and a while and wont register (luckily they sometimes wont register back) -
Too many bonfires -
Message rating system isn't as convient due to trolls (I don't count this as a big negative, just an annoying scenario)


Side notes:
I don't as many games as I used, so this definitely satisfied my cravings for the time being, it's possible the only single/multiplayer hybrid game I've restarted played after beating. Have at thee!

reviewText:
The great feeling of finally beating the boss you've been trying to kill for over 10 times, doing so with wit, skill and some experience from all those previous deaths. To pile up your own corpses to finally reach as high as the bar of difficulty that a boss requires. And interesting combat system that is responsive, fair and most of the time entertaining to partake in. Blocks, parries, rolls, magic, archery, basically all you want from a medieval fantasy world.

The story is barely non existant, as well as it should be as you're not there for the story. Your accomplishments come from overcoming hurdles, not learing about the character development of various people in the game. You get a few tid bits from there and there, enjoying what little they give you without taking away from the focus, the game is difficult.

The combat is most of the time fair, however a lot of cheap moves from bosses and other difficult mobs make it sometimes frustrating when a insta kill move come out of nowhere, dying because you've not faced that enemy just yet. Assuming, requiring you to die to learn a certain move set by a certain mob is unfair in its combat system and that is what my main complaint about the game is... To my taste, it's something that is rather cheeky, an attempt to keep the You will die" idea up by forcing it onto you.

The game is a single player focused game

reviewText:
Yes, very recommended but...only for those who played Demon's Souls or Dark Souls and want some more without high expectations about the story.

In general terms I really loved Dark Souls II. First Souls game with native HD and beyond resolutions for PC. Also the 60 FPS was a very important must". The plot and lore are not that great as Dark Souls PTDE but it has his own good moments.

This new entry is full of new items and some other little interesting mechanics like the coffin of Things Betwixt
date:
the life gems and some new covenants. It was fun to discover them through the game.

The humanity thing remains but this time is easier to handle. In general Dark Souls II has a lot of things to make the difficulty of newcomers easier (wich I recommend you don't abuse if you played a Souls before).

About Souls and leveling this time you do it between Emerald Gerald in Majula. Similar to the Maiden in Black from Demon's Souls Nexus.

About visual and sound...mmm... Visually is not mind blowing but is an step forward from PC Dark Souls with DS Fix. The art looks fantastic in lighting terms. Maybe is different in it's style in terms of environments and enemies design. A lot more cliche but enjoyable. Oh! rag doll is off in this game...and the lighting and assets from it's first gameplay shown to the world ¬¬

The sound design (foley etc) is good. But the music score is something I recommend you didn't expect to be better than previous games. But is good!...Take listen to Demon's Souls for instance. It has some interesting flutes and leitmotifs wich are missing on the next game. I find the Intro
recommended:
Phalanx or the adjudicator one the most memorable ones. In Dark Souls there's a great variety of styles and there's even more memorable songs. And unfortunate for those who love the music of this games Dark Souls II is kind of flat...epic but flat. That doesn't mean i doesn't have it's moments ;)

About the important thing...Gameplay. It's almost the same but more responsive and smooth. The kick was replaced for the shoulder push. But there's a lot more weapon styles even bare hands styles. I find my self on PvP with players with very strange setups xD and of course two hackers in a few months (I'm not very expect on the PvP thing). The only downside here is that "Soul Memory System" wich is not optional.

The co-op. Now you can summon two players the NPC of the area you're (if it's available) and an internet player. This can make the game much easier. I don't recommend this much. I find myself solving some bosses with this method and then feeling horrible haha. But never again!

Mmmm Boss Fights...they're not that interesting as the areas they're on. But there are some of this friends wich you'll hate at the same level as before.

I think Dark Souls II is not a bad entry at all (BTW Hidetaka Miyazaki just supervised it but it wasn't it's director). We can't say is a bad game. Maybe a transition. I think it's better than have a hole until Bloodborne is released and of course it deserves it's price ;)"

reviewText:
Dark Souls II is a great game, no matter what anyone will say. It is -not- the same as the first Dark Souls though. Level design is linear, a lot of mobs and bosses are poorly designed and forgettable (though there are a few hidden gems). On the other hand, the PvP is infinitely better than the previous title; fastrolling Havelmonsters are still a thing, but lagstabs are... Slightly less of an issue, and even though From has been a bit heavy-handed when managing their balance tweaking, nerfing some things so hard as to make them unusable and buffing others to the degree of nonsense (Looking at you, here, Red Iron Winblade), it remains a wonderful game.

If you enjoyed Demon's or Dark Souls, you will enjoy this. But you might not enjoy it as much if you are one who likes to focus solely on PvE. Though you might want to wait with buying it if you haven't already, and instead wait 'til April for Scholar of the First Sin edition.

TL;DR: Great game, albeit with worse PvE than previous titles. On the plus side, improved PvP.

Overall a great game, very very recommended.

reviewText: Playing Dark Souls II reminds me of old video games like Into The Eagles Nest and Ghosts and Goblins where the technology was so limited that enemies were ultimately fair, tutorials were non-existent, and I didn't mind playing the same level over and over memorizing and perfecting it.  Dark Souls isnt exactly fun all the time, but it is engaging and satisfying.  Its more like a challenge, keep that in mind as you calibrate your expectations and you can get over the initial steep learning curve.  I died at least 4 times before the tutorial section even started.  But the tutorial was actually effective if you pay attention and attempt to apply it as the game continues.  The story is very light and absorbed through infrequent NPC character dialogue so it is importatnt that you aren't expecting a strong story or character driven narrative.  The difficulty ramp has been even over time, with the exception of bosses which are very short and brutal until you get the hang of that particular boss.  As you progress, the enemies become more varied so to encourage varied tactics from encounter to encounter.  This is not a game with which you can check-out and just enjoy.  You have to focus on the enemies actions and responding appropriately.  There are no exclamation points to warn you of an incoming attack.  The game requires that you use all of the available mechanics, first order optimizations will only lead to frequent deaths and frustration.  The enemies have access to all of the same abilities as you, the player.  In this way, it is scrupulously fair.  Ambushes are always detectable if you are paying attention.  No monster closets or enemies popping into existence because you crossed a threshold. It is a game to focus on and feel satisfied when you succeed.  So far, I am really enjoying it.\n\nNote: I didn't play Dark Souls or Demon Souls.  I havent engaged in any multiplayer, though it exists in a coop form where friends can help you with boss fights and a PVP form where presumably frustrating people do frustrating things.

reviewText:
The way ahead is completely covered in darkness. Apart from a few points of light in the distance and the orange glow that comes from the bonfire behind you, you can't see anything. You decide to light your torch, which casts its light over a small area around you. You don`t have much oil left to keep it burning, but it will have to do. Cautiously, you start moving.

After scouting the location a little, you realize you are at the top of a big rock overlooking a dock. In the far distance, an immense ghost ship lies floating in the water. Somehow you feel that's where you are supposed to go.

The path from the rock to the docks leads you through an abandoned village, now inhabited only by the undead. Creeping from every corner, they lunge at you from the darkness. Street after street and house after house you make battle with them, getting each time closer to the docks. The voyage takes more time than you previously expected though, and soon your weapon begins to degrade from beating against the metal your enemies were wearing at the time of their deaths.

Soon, you find yourself with just an almost broken sword, no more healing items and a torch whose light is about to fade away. You are, however, much closer to the ship. You can see it more clearly now, its ragged sails wavering in the wind, calling you. Taking a deep breath, you go for the final stretch of the journey, hoping your now depleted inventory will be able to get you there in one piece.

You find the bell that calls the ship to port just as the light of your torch finally dies. This is it, you`ve made it. Now all you must do is board the ship and hopefully a bonfire will be waiting for you at the deck. What you find inside though, is disappointing: more enemies. They are dispatched quickly but that doesn't do any good to your already worn off sword.

You find the stairs leading to the ship`s quarters. That has to be it. By the end of these steps you hope only to find the long awaited bonfire, a place where you can rest, recover your healing items and fix your gear. Step after step you descend anxiously, turning the camera at the end to explore the room at which you arrive.

The room is empty, except for a table, some chairs and... a fog door, which indicates a boss fight is imminent.  That's all you didn't need right now. Without any means to recover your health and carrying only a dull blade, the terrifying prospect of having to walk through that entire dark place all over again starts to creep up on you. Without any other choice, you buckle up and cross the damned gate.

The vision that greets you is terrifying. A pair of giant skeletons, bound to each other like siamese twins, each armed with a pair of blades are already walking towards you, their feet chirping in the water that covers the floor of the flooded room. Without any items to recover your health, you know you can't afford to take even a single hit. So you raise your shield and keep your distance, studying the movements of the beast. After avoiding a few of its attacks you start feeling confident and are able to deliver them a few hits when their guard is down.

The fight progresses slowly, as you only attack when you are sure it's safe to. The boss' movements are easy to predict and it starts to feel that victory will be yours, so long as you keep your strategy going.

The skeletons' health drops to its half. Again they move to deliver the same pattern of attacks they've been doing since the beginning of the fight. You know how to react: just roll to the right, wait for them to raise their blades again, roll again to the right... and unexpectedly get hit in the face by a blow that totally shouldn't have gotten you. What happened? You were able to dodge all of their attacks so far, but this last one hit you despite you having done exactly the same movements as before.

As you try to gain some distance from the creature, you notice you are moving slower. Why is this happening? The fight that was almost a sure victory has become a real nightmare. As the monster lifts his blades in the air for yet another blow, you realize in terror what has been going on: the water level in the room has been steadily rising since you entered the area.

Welcome to Dark Souls.

reviewText:
Just buy the game. Seriously, just do it. Dark Souls 2 is everything and more you want from a sequel. It is fun, frustrating (what did you expect?), and challenging.

However, you people love listing pros and cons, so here we go:

Pros:
- Graphics are beautiful.
- Gameplay is awesome.
- Challenging, slightly increased difficulty from Dark Souls (1).
- Varied monsters, combat and scenery.

Cons:
- The PC controls. It is a bit tricky, I had some trouble adjusting to this part. However, for me it was easier to change the following:
- Some bosses are overly influenced by the previous game.

Left click - Attack right weapon
Double Left click - Strong attack, right weapon
Right click - Block
Double Right click - Parry
Q - Use item
E - Interact

For more advanced players who might enjoy PvP:
R: Strong attack, left weapon (parry).
V: Attack, right weapon (if combined with W, this makes a shoulder push).


Hope this helped, and have fun!
