reviewText: Playing Dark Souls II reminds me of old video games like Into The Eagles Nest and Ghosts and Goblins where the technology was so limited that enemies were ultimately fair, tutorials were non-existent, and I didn't mind playing the same level over and over memorizing and perfecting it.  Dark Souls isnt exactly fun all the time, but it is engaging and satisfying.  Its more like a challenge, keep that in mind as you calibrate your expectations and you can get over the initial steep learning curve.  I died at least 4 times before the tutorial section even started.  But the tutorial was actually effective if you pay attention and attempt to apply it as the game continues.  The story is very light and absorbed through infrequent NPC character dialogue so it is importatnt that you aren't expecting a strong story or character driven narrative.  The difficulty ramp has been even over time, with the exception of bosses which are very short and brutal until you get the hang of that particular boss.  As you progress, the enemies become more varied so to encourage varied tactics from encounter to encounter.  This is not a game with which you can check-out and just enjoy.  You have to focus on the enemies actions and responding appropriately.  There are no exclamation points to warn you of an incoming attack.  The game requires that you use all of the available mechanics, first order optimizations will only lead to frequent deaths and frustration.  The enemies have access to all of the same abilities as you, the player.  In this way, it is scrupulously fair.  Ambushes are always detectable if you are paying attention.  No monster closets or enemies popping into existence because you crossed a threshold. It is a game to focus on and feel satisfied when you succeed.  So far, I am really enjoying it.\n\nNote: I didn't play Dark Souls or Demon Souls.  I havent engaged in any multiplayer, though it exists in a coop form where friends can help you with boss fights and a PVP form where presumably frustrating people do frustrating things.

reviewText: Is it as good as the first game? Actually, yes. The mechanics in this game are refined and flushed out in lacking areas, while fat was trimmed from flawed areas (like weapon upgrading) in the prior titles. This game has issues, just like Dark souls 1 had, but they are different issues, and while they bother some individuals (like myself) more than the issues of the first Dark souls game, others may find this game a refreshing step forward for the franchise. A worthy purchase, especially if you can catch it on sale. If you are looking for a populated multiplayer experience as your main draw, however, I will point you kindly to the playstation version, as that community will assuredly remain the most active in PvP

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong by this recommendation. I love Dark Souls 2 (and I think I'm one of the few that like it better than Dark Souls 1). But...

...If you are new to the Souls series, or don't yet own Dark Souls 2 for the PC, don't buy this game. Wait until Scholar of the First Sin comes out in 2015 (currently slated to be released in April). It is purported to be a vastly improved experience, with new enemies, NPCs, and quests - along with improved graphics. It will run in DX11, so make sure your computer will be able to handle it.

I DON'T like the fact that they will make the people who already own Dark Souls 2 re-purchase a game that is essentially an updated/patched version. It would be one thing if it were a DLC patch. But buying the entire game again and (most likely) losing all game progress? Not to mention the two games will be on differnt servers and thus unable to play with one another, thus splitting the already-limited community. What the hell, From Software? That's an incredibly unethical business practice if I've ever seen one. It makes EA, Ubisoft, and Activision look ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed consumer-concious by comparison.

Sigh. Not sure if I'm actually going to buy the new game or not. I want the better version, but I don't want to support a blatant cash-grab that is clearly just aiming to milk our wallets. Purchase it, or don't. It's entirely up to you. I probably won't.

reviewText:
So i've recently been asked to write a full review of this game while completely ignoring that its a part of the souls series. As such i'm going to do just that.

While the game is not a bad game it is flawed in many ways. Allow me to explain why.

1 - Being hard

Now, i say that its hard, but I'm not complaining about it being hard in the traditional sense. I'm not asking for an easier game either since in my opinion that'd be 20 kinds of dumb.

I'm complaining about this because, while i enjoy a good challenging game, this game is hard just for the sake of being hard.

Allow me to exemplify. There is an optional area in the game where the boss consists of 4 minions and the boss itself. The boss is untargetable until you attack one of the 4 minions, meaning you can't weaken him before commencing the fight. As for the minions, the second you attack one of them the remaining 3 immediately become agressive and attack you giving you around 5 seconds or so to dispatch them before the boss drops into the area and begins attacking you as well. This would be fine if the minions didn't inflict a status effect that deals a large ammount of damage over time with a mere 2 hits. This means you have to deal with the 4 minions, as quickly as possible, without getting hit twice and possibly have to deal with the boss itself should you fail to dispatch the critters in time.

This is not what i'd call challenging, but as a gigantic pain the the neck instead. This isn't the only fight where this happens, but i'd rather not delve too much into it.

2 - Combat

While combat itself is pretty okay, i have some problems with it. Call it nitpicking if you will but there are just some things that don't really feel right.

The hitboxes feel off sometimes, there's no other way to describe it, while playing i'll sometimes  see the effect caused by a weapon clearly hitting my opponent without it actually happening, and it makes me wonder if something is actually wrong with either my game or my computer.

Another interesting little thing is that enemies never grow tired. The game itself has a stamina mechanic that forces you to think before you act, but enemies can dish out a flurry of attacks even though (from the story's/game perspective), they're in the same pseudo-zombified state as the player, the same can be said for their attack tracking ability, by this i mean there are certain enemies that will literally turn 180 degrees while in the middle of an attack just so they can attempt to hit you (in fact this was so bad in one specific enemy, that the developers actually had to reduce the tracking capabilities on said enemy's projectiles).

This feels a bit off, and dare I say, makes the game harder, just for the sake of being harder.

3 - Covenants.

This'll be a short one. You have no idea what you're getting yourself into. That's it. when you interact with someone or something that allows you to join a covenant, you get no information about what you're getting yourself into. In fact this occurred to a good friend of mine. While he was playing he found an object that allowed him to join a covenant, simply asking him if he's ready to face a bigger challenge. He then found out that by entering this covenant his damage was reduced and that he was unable to summon any NPCs or players into his world for help.

I may be mistaken, but there are several several possible outcomes when one decides do say that something will result in a bigger challenge. Usually people who decide to face a bigger challenge know what sort of mess they're getting themselves into.

This isn't the case.

4 - NPCs

Interaction with NPCs isn't really anything to write home about in most games, but some things in Dark Souls 2 annoy me.

Allow me to exemplify. In this game you are only allowed to level up by speaking with one specific NPC. Now instead of opening the menu and letting said NPC talk while you're navigating through the menu you are forced to skip 4 dialogue segments before you are finally allowed to level up.

Now, in this game you'll be interacting with this NPC quite a few times, seeing as this is the NPC that allows you to increase the number of innate healing items you possess in your inventory along with allowing you to level up. The result is that these interactions" become extremely annoying extremely early in the game. Truth be told this is not something that should happen when you're dealing with an "important" NPC
date:
or any other NPC for that matter.

5 - PvP

Last but not least
recommended: we have PvP. An addition to the game that should be fun filled
hoursPlayed:
challenging and overall allow the player to enjoy him/herself even more.

If it was actually balanced that is.

Now in PvP (or Invasions) your goal is to either defeat the invader or the invaded (depending on whether you're invading or being invaded)
voteText: but lets talk about accessing PvP first. there are 3 main PvP covenants within the game. One of them grants you a ring that automatically summons you into one of two areas in the game where you must face off against the player that set foot within that area. As a reward for this you get titanite chunks
helpfulPercent: which are relatively hard to come by and allow you to reinforce your weapons and armor.\n\nThe remaining two covenants make mostly use of cracked eye orbs (although one of these covenants gives you a ring that allows you to aid players from another covenant while said players are being invaded). The thing is
votesHelpful: in your first playthrough
votesTotal: you are only given access to a limited number of orbs
votesFunny: making invasions during your first (and possibly even last) playthrough limited as well. Please note that these covenants require an immense ammount of invasions for the player to rank up (requiring a total of 500 victories for the player to achieve the third and final rank).\n\nAs for a way of replenishing eye orbs the player is given two options. Duel against players from the same covenant or buy them for a ridiculous ammount of souls in New Game +. Dueling on its own is a pain because you have to consume a different token for each covenant (these are obtained by either using eye orbs and defeating an invaded player
commentsCount: or by aiding another player as a phantom).\n\nAs a result
column16:
invasions during a player's first playthrough are extremely rare should you decide not to venture into the area protected by the 1st mentioned PvP covenant.

That aside there is also the case of extreme unbalance. The game features spells that can easily instantly kill a player for a measly soul cost or buff already hard hitting weapons along with weapons with a ridiculous attack speed or maybe even phantom reach (meaning that their reach is longer than it actually appears to be).

My main issue with this is that some of the builds that focus on using these spells/weapons
column17: are relatively easy to make
column18: and as a result my PvP experience went downhill at an astonishing speed.\n\nWeaponry aside
column19: invaders are unable to recover HP without resorting to spells. Making it so that even if the invading is actually fighting well
column20: and in a fair way
column21: nothing is stopping the invaded player from running away/hiding so that he/she may recover HP and then rush back into the fight without almost any form of punishment whatsoever. This just helps make PvP even more unbalanced (not to mention the fact that a player may summon 2 other players to their aid
column22:
turning the fight into a 3 vs 1 where the opposing trio has the ability to regenerate health).

6 - Conclusion

Please note that these are my opinions and that people are free to disagree with me
column23: its also likely that its just me who's just bad at the game in which case i've been trying to git gud for a very long time
column24: but the game as a whole has several blatant design flaws once you take a very good look at it
column25: and while it is good on its own
column26: it could have been a much better game in the end. So while i do recommend this game
column27: i'd wait for a discount."

reviewText:
I haven’t played Dark Souls 1 or its predecessor Demon Souls so I can’t speak to how similar Dark Souls II (DS2) is to either of them. I can say however that if the previous games are as hard as DS2, I probably don’t want to play those either. I only played this game for a few hours so keep that in mind when weighing my opinion.

In DS2 you start the game as some sort of undead being. You are warned about the dangers of becoming “Hollow” which I guess is a kind of damned spirit. The game’s narration has the feel of a dream where you’re not entirely sure what’s going on but you have an idea of what you’re supposed to do. The game follows your progress towards reaching “The King” (and probably fighting him). Obviously I didn’t get far enough to see how that works out. There are a number of neutral people that you meet on your quest that you can talk to or interact with, but large portions of the game world seem uninhabited. By the way, some of the people can be hard to see since they blend into the environment very well (people kind of sit around in random places). I’m used to games where objects and people have some sort of highlight around them to improve visibility.

I was a little disappointed in the game’s graphics to be honest. I thought that being a modern game DS2 would have slick high definition gameplay, but actually the textures are similar to older games such as Darksiders 2. I’m not saying it’s bad (it’s still pretty good), just that I expected a 2014 AAA title to be amazing. One bright side to this is that my 3 year old computer didn’t have any problems running the game. The game is clearly a console port so playing on a game controller is strongly recommended. Since I have very little experience using controllers (I don’t own any consoles) I first tried Keyboard + Mouse. This didn’t work out so well since performing even basic actions would require combinations of keys. For example, the “action” button would be shift+left click. And when using keyboard + mouse, the on-screen prompts would be for controller keys (Press A button to pick up item). After a few hours play I still haven’t figured out how to put items on the “quick use” belt.

When people describe the Dark Souls games probably the first thing mentioned is usually the difficulty. The game is very hard because you have no “advantage” over any of your enemies. It takes them only a few hits to kill you just as it takes you a few hits to kill them. You also have a stamina bar which limits how often you can swing your weapon. This means you can’t just dive into a battle chopping with your sword and hope that you make the first strike. There are no “weak” enemies; everyone can all kill you in seconds if you’re not paying attention. And if you die, you lose ALL your money/experience and respawn with lower max health. The money/experience of the game is counted in “souls” which are used as both currency and experience for leveling up. You have an opportunity to retrieve the souls you drop on death, but if you die again before picking them up (happens a lot because enemies respawn), they’re lost permanently. I can only imagine what some of the later boss battles must be like.

Pros:
+The game can be immersive and is actually fair. Every time you die you’ll kick yourself because you know that if you had done it “right” you wouldn’t have died.
+I like how the money and experience is combined into “souls” which are automatically gained on killing an enemy. I get easily tired of looting corpses in RPGs.
+The game is challenging and I’m sure you’d feel like a god if you actually beat it.

Cons:
-Dark Souls 2 is too hard for me. If you didn’t have your life bar shrunk with every death I wouldn’t mind doing some grinding, but as it is the game just gets harder and harder as you die.
-The controls (even with a controller) can be hard to master if you’re not experienced with this kind of game. The platform jumping was especially annoying for me since it takes a combination of buttons to accomplish a simple jump. And if you fall, you die.
-The level up system is not very well explained. You start at around level 12 depending on what class you chose and you’re not told very clearly how many souls you need per level up. On level up you get to increase 1 stat, and it’s not clearly explained what each stat does. I’m sure I could read up on it online before playing the game, but I don’t like having to research a game before playing.
-The game has no “objective clues” or game map. You’re just given this large game world to explore at random.

Overall I’m not going to recommend the game unless you’ve played the previous ones. All of the cons I mentioned would probably melt away after you’ve played through the game at least once. I thought the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games were weak too but I enjoyed them after playing through at least one time. Then you’d know where to go and what you need to do (including what order you should explore areas in). If you’ve never played the previous Dark Souls games and don’t like super challenging games, stay away from Dark Souls II until the price drops. The game has a meta rating over 90% so most people must love it. If you really must try it, gather your patience and do a lot of pre-game research.

reviewText:
This game is by far one of the BEST Rpg games I've played. Prepare to Die, Prepare to know your skill, Prepare to Improve. I cannot stress enough on how fun this game is. The mechanics of the game are made to counter the Hack-and-Slash point of view. (That means slashing like crazy with no bad side-effects) Where as this game if you don't plan your attacks right, if you don't try to out-think your opponents you will die, or be punished harshly. When I started playing this it made me realize that there is a MAJOR SKILL-CAP to this game. Of course there are multi-player functions, but you'll be soloing more often on mobs.

And

The PvP in the game is FORCED! This means that you'll have some really good npc's that are very player-like that will hand you your head on a platter if you don't think through what you're doing, and players will INVADE your game. This makes the game much more fun and adding a sense of OMG I DID IT!" When you get your first player kill.

Although there are some really bad sides to the game. Such as the Bell Tower. If you go in there prepared to be invaded by 3 people. So it's best to get a squad of your own before you enter the area to fight the gargoyle (optional boss).

Worried about hackers? - Most of the main areas before bosses have been developed to knock off hackers with infinite hp
date:
but they're a very small portion of the community and it isn't likely that you'll encounter one. Over all the time I've played I fought 1 hacker in the undead crypt. He ran at me with infinite hp and I shot him off the cliff using a giant arrow.

This is a 100% purchase for people who want to be tested on their ability. When you start a quick suggestion is to think "Hey what type of class do I want my person to be?" Look up some guides for things like that. I also suggest a PARRY GUIDE. Especially for those people who love dual wield. Becoming good at parrying helps a lot (not for bosses though).


Notes: Take your time. And there is one difficulty : DIFFICULT  But you'll get use to it quite fast.

and in the words of Illidan
recommended: if you are not ready to experience a skill-check as well as having a fullfilling satisfaction then...\n\n"YOU ARE NOT PREPARED!"  And prepare to die... and have fun!"

Fighting for my life against three enemies and a distant archer, I accidentaly hit a man in armor that refused to talk to me. He then proceeded to demonstrate how sharp his blade was and I died once again.

10/10 will play until I go hollow

reviewText: as of 4/26/2014 due to a VAC Ban on my Profile - I have to go over to my Alt account and family share in order to Access the game online - The downside is that I am going to be unable to play that main character on this account - Although I made two characters on this account in the exctremely boring OFFLINE" mode - Dark Souls II and the use of Multiplayer is 10000 times more important and implemented for pure strength; unlike Dark Souls 1; which from launch (Me and my buddy TRIED invading eachother; we TRIED getting in touch with eachother in game; but .... Games for windows Live sucked and we couldn't connect to eachother no matter what we tried - Thus I never completed DS1; I loved it - but in comparison to DS2 - I'd go as far as to say that DS1 was highly over-rated... Dark Souls II is the real deal.\n\n- As a PC owner you have a few different options for even prettier graphics than it launches with as well (it launches quite nice looking; and far better looking than the console versions - (Thank god Form Software figured a lot of things out and did them RIGHT this time) - With Nvidia Inspector you can use the Diablo 3 Ambient Occlusion profile; you can set up REALLY great looking AA and add FXAA with it; and you can set up HBAO+ (Gotta Love being an Nvidia User :D) - Then software allows you to DOWNSCALE RESOLUTIONS! So I set mine to 7680x4320 (Resolution; thus upping the resolution of all the textures --of everything-- to 7680x4320 then downsampling down to my Monitor's display resolution of 1920x1080 which = GORGEOUS BEYOND BELIEF - Doing this while ALSO adding the Ambient Occlusion
date: AA and HBAO+ is stunning (and trust me; you really dont even need Anti-Aliasing when you are Upping the Resolution on all the textures 4-5x times what "Highest" would be; - This is brilliant; and with my SLI 780 ti's I've never dipped any FPS due to having it at 7680x4320 - It runs 100% smooth and never dips out in large fights or multiplayer interaction - I believe this is the highest I will go for now; I will see it if actually supports higher texture resolution downsampling than that... if it does - then hell.. Why not!!??\n\nThe game itself is just plain addiction; it is the Heroin of game launches (thus far this year atlesst :P ) - It may not be as "Hard" as some people make it out to be; but I got my self stuck in a situation where I kept dying over and over (and lost 2.5K souls; which at the time was two level ups >.< where the Tough (but pretty darn easy) mosnter was right next to the Camp; so I'd just farm him and goto the fire - reset; then to my surprise he was //No Longer Farmable// - (This was unlike DS1) - So I pushed on and got whooped at the second enemy after him due to a wrongly timed dodge; and an embarressing jumping strike that did make contact but also sent me flying 1
recommended: 000 feet to my death; I can imagine all the players around that area at the time clicking on my bloodstain and seeing that; just laughing outloud - Speaking of which; The descriptive abilities for "Helpful Tips" from other players are actually "helpful" now; as you can type whatever in a longer amount of characters - You'll also find some trolls with (Honestly
hoursPlayed:
amusing!) notes near the edge of cliffs "Jump down and hug the left side for treasure chest" I see about 10 bloodstains and watch these people just fall to their deaths.... Obviously no treasure - and I get quite a laugh out of it; "Tools" -rapid screenshotting-

Co-op with your buddies changes DS2 for the Better 1000%; and invading other worlds with them and ganking is more fun in DS2 than in any RPG I can think of - Also with the "Jedi Knight Multiplayer" style "Honor system" people will bow prior to engaging in an actual duel; and allow themselves and the enemy to buff up (this is mostly end game from what people told me as I partook in these rituals; although doing it at an earlier level starts the great "PVP Community" mindset;
With that said; I'll still gank someone who is not in it for the duel; but in it for why I'll gank them - just to appear and grab the kill while I am in the middle of a fight; thus why I chose to go with the starting item that has any mob near me aggro the outside;

What can I say? Dark Souls II was MORE than WORTH THE WAIT for the PC Version - I do own a PS3; and for titles such as The Last of Us etc I will grab those excellent AAA titles that won't see daylight on PC - With Dark Souls II just as in any other title that has a release date on PC MONTHS after the console release date; I'll just wait it out - I have a friend who did not; and now aside from myself; other people he reguarly gamed with all have it on PC; and he is thinking about getting it on PC - I just sort of think the initial waiting was worth it; as we had plenty of new games to fill the time on PC prior to the DSII launch (Diablo 3 RoS for example if its the RPG funny bone that needs to be tickled) -
More than worth the wait - and as nearly every reveiw states...
"This is the ULTIMATE DARK SOULS 2 EXPERIENCE" or "This is now the only Dark Souls II version that gamers should buy" "The Definitive Version of Dark Souls II" - "Makes The Dark Souls II I loved on my PS3 feel 10 years older" - etc :D

reviewText:
Disclaimer:

I suggest to start with Matthewmatosis's review where all of the problems of DS2 are summarized:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UScsme8didI

____
My playtime for DS1 was about 110h.
I gave DS2 a several tries and finally completed brining a total playtime to 67h.

I guess in the end there are two major fractions of the Souls fanbase:

* The fans of the game (this group complains about stuff like lore and immersion)
* The fans of the metagame (this group very notably demand you to have at least 200 hours in the game to be able to voice any kind of opinion).

For the second group DS2 is on pair or maybe even better than the DS1 with better fps, better pvp, larger variety of weapons and overall better mechanic. I think they don't really care about the game itself as the artistic product, but merely as a medium for their metagaming experience. Convenience is all about metagame and DS2 is definitely more convenient.

For the first group DS is all about the game experience and the immersion. And from this point of view DS2 is absolutely abysmal. Every single design decision of the DS2 is simply not working in favor of game. What's worse, every bad design decision triggers a cascade of other problems and they snowball.

* Levels are poorly connected, and often make no sense thematically.
* NPC are completely uninteresting and too verbose.
* The lore and story are virtually non existing.
* Bosses are repetitive, often use the same movesets and are mostly recycled versions of other enemies.
* Soul memory is not really working in favor of local coop.
* Closely placed bonfires break immersion.
* You have to go back to hub to level up which breaks immersion even more.
* If you are using rings of protection you are completely deprived of any sense of challenge.
* If you are not using ring of protection, you are faced with extremely limited human effigies and inability to farm them (as monsters are limited in this game).

I can go on and on about it, but I guess you can get my point.

reviewText:
I can't even begin to explain how disappointing this game was.

From Software, all you had to do was fix connecting to other players, and add proper 60FPS to the game. Not only are those things STILL broken, and not to mention we learn more and more every day about how terrible the implementation of 60fps is in the game, but you also had to ruin almost everything else that made the original game fun.

The near perfect hitboxes of the first game? Completely gone, and now you can guarantee dying every so often for the dumbest things.

The fair balance of rolling? Also gone. It baffles me how any developer could think that tying i-frames to a stat was a good idea. The point of having a fixed amount of i-frames was so players could actually GET GOOD at dodging and KNOWING when they would be invincible during a roll instead of having near-zero invincibility at low levels and then having a hard time to adjust once they did have a good amount of i-frames in their rolls.

The realistic movement? Once again, gone. Welcome the new floaty movement that feels like you're always ice skating instead of walking on solid ground. Oh and also the way equipment weight affects movement is ridiculous as well, making you look like a bouncing balloon instead of an actual person.

Now on to weapons. Not only have the movesets been worsened, but now it feels like you're swinging a foam sword instead of having any actual weight behind it. They clearly did not use mo-cap for this game, or in the case that they did use it, made  terrible use of its advantages.

The world map makes no sense whatsoever, and the interconnectivity from the first game is non-existant. It's all straight pathways from now on. Not only this, but none of the areas are as good as the original game's environments. They are incredibly inconsistent and far from grounded and realistic.

Alright, now the enemies. You thought it would get better from here in the review right? WRONG. Humanoids humanoids humanoids EVERYWHERE. No originality whatsoever. But that isn't a huge deal, you know what is though? The fact that the game throws wave after wave of AWFUL enemies in groups of 4 to 5 enemies at you because LEL DERK SULZ IS HERRRD" instead of putting you against 1 or 2 difficult enemies that have interesting fighting styles. It also sucks that almost every single enemy in the game has a 'one-shot' move in which you get stuck in a dumb animation where all you'll find to say is "How in the f*** did he grab me? I WAS 3 METERS AWAY!". All in all your deaths from these enemies with the smarts of a zombie will always leave you flabbergasted as to how you actually died.

Finally
date: the bosses. Ohhh how great it was when you first encountered O&S
recommended: and later when you fought Artorias. The bosses were hard at first
hoursPlayed: but all you needed to do was adjust to their attacks and switch up strategies. They had unique fight styles which engaged the players and every death felt like it was YOUR fault instead of leaving you screaming at the monitor about how unfair the Ancient Dragon's attacks are. But that's not it
voteText: the game applies the same logic to bosses that they apply to enemies. It's no longer a fair fight where you can focus on the boss. No. Now the game puts you against MORE than one boss at a time
helpfulPercent: all with their own ridiculous hitboxes just for your enjoyment. Oh
votesHelpful: and they are almost all humanoids too
votesTotal: and none of them are remarkable from the rest.\n\nI could probably go into how terrible the lore and story is in Dark Souls 2
votesFunny: but I think just remembering how poor this game was has left enough disappointment in me for today.\n\nPS : Get gud casuls"

reviewText: Ruined expectations: The game.\nWhere do I begin? The PvE is okay but nowhere near as good as in DaS1 or DeS: bosses are forgettable, most NPCs are there only for the purpose of buying items and nothing more, the OST is lacking, the ending was terrible and so was the final boss.\nThe PvP is outright broken, great" mechanics such as Soul Memory allow SL838s and SL150s to fight each other just because they have gained enough souls to be in the same SM range. It ends up with everyone using the same build since holding back on leveling up will leave yourself in disadvantage. Full Havel's/Santier's/Avelyns/hexes/monastery. Where's the fun in fighting that and just that? Not to mention that full Havel's makes your damage a joke. The PvP in the Souls series was always all about creating new imaginative builds and learning how to handle them with skill. In DaS1 or DeS your armor didn't really matter as much as it does here. An SL1 could beat an SL500 with a certain amount of skill. Not here
date:
because the new engine makes controlling your character nowhere as good.
I finished DS1 in 80 hours and the rest were put in PvP because there was always fun in making and fighting different builds. I don't have the motivation to continue playing this game. It's not possible to have fun while soul memory is a thing. I have many doubts that it will go away but we can only hope that it does.

Only worth purchasing on a sale for PvE. In its current state it's not worth buying if you're willing to buy it for the PvP that comes afterwards."

reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 is a decent game, but it is inferior to Dark Souls.

Dark Souls 2 has managed to become a reptitive game to play, in comparison to Dark Souls. In Dark Souls 2, areas are smaller and more densely packed with enemies. In some cases, there are far too many enemies to take on without backpedaling and turtling, making getting through an area a slow process. There's many more respawn points put throughout the game, so you won't have to backtrack far if you die, but the sheer volume and tankiness of enemies makes short distances seem much longer. There's also less alternate routes to take while progressing through the game; many more of the areas are unskippable, which exacerbates the problem of enemy-saturated areas. Unlike Dark Souls, starting a new game with a character that has finished the game (called new game+, or NG+) will spawn new enemies and surprises for you to deal with. This is a nice addition, and it keeps the game fresh for a bit longer. However, many of the new enemies the game will throw at you are just very tanky and further repeats of those areas just take longer than they did before.

Multiplayer in Dark Souls 2 is a straight downgrade from Dark Soul's multiplayer. In the Dark Souls series, you level up using the game's currency, souls". You get souls from killing creatures in the game world
date: and it is inevitable you will get souls by progressing through the game. Previously
recommended: the level of your character determined what other players you could be matched with in Dark Souls. You could go through the game at a low level and still be able to connect to players near the beginning of the game; this allowed for overpowered co-op partners who could take out bosses very quickly
hoursPlayed: or overpowered enemy PvPers who could one-shot you. Late game
voteText: players stopped leveling at a community-decided level cap that allowed players to continue connecting to one another. The level cap encouraged players to optimize their character builds within these constraints for maximum specialization toward whatever role they wanted.\n\nBecause of the imbalanced early-game PvP in Dark Souls

reviewText:
Dark Souls II is an amazing game.

I often give it a really hard time, because I love it so much. If I were to make a scale of how I rate my games, this would be it:

(BEST) Dark Souls - - - - - Dark Souls 2 - - - - - - - - - - - - - *Everything Else* (WORST)

In the shadow of Dark Souls, I often rail at this game for some problems. Sure, giving so many enemies infinite poise was a terrible idea. Putting basically every enemy and boss on swivels so that their missed combos aren't punished is absolutely a bad one too. And yeah, scrapping the theme of darkness mattering and just padding the game with extra enemies is quite annoying, and the netcode hitbox is arguably much worse than the first one...

...but all things considered, the game is still incredible, and a definite must-play. While I believe it resides in the great shadow that is the incredible Dark Souls, it's still leagues above basically every other game.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is not for the faint of heart, and not quite like anything you've ever played before. There are no easy enemies, no easy areas. Every battle can be your last, every corner a death trap. It's brutal, but fair.
It stands as testament that a true challenge makes the whole experience so much more satisfying, when you battle the biggest, baddest enemy you've encountered yet and finally best it.

Great atmosphere, great gameplay, huge replayability and some brilliant dynamic multiplayer interaction which seamlessy blends into gameplay.

reviewText:
When I saw that Lord Gaben had put this game on a 50% sale, I had to buy it, seeing as I had already spent a lot of time with it on the Xbox 360, but had never had an opportunity to play the multiplayer, due to my Xbox not being connected to the internet and whatnot.

Many notable things have happened throughout my playtime of this game. I shall tell of a few of them.

-put down summon sign in front of smelter demon fog gate to farm sunlight medals
-got summoned
-praised sun 5 times
-walked toward fog gate
-walked off cliff
-died instantly
-did not get sunlight medal


-invaded person's world in harvest valley
-found person
-person did not move
-backstabbed person
-person took no damage
-backstabbed person 7 more times
-person took no damage
-person began to move, lagging all over the place
-followed person
-severe lag spike occured
-lag spike ended
-found that i had been backstabbed and slashed several times
-died


-touched red summon sign in old iron keep to initiate pvp
-began to fight
-was doing pretty decent
-windows notification minimized game
-frantically unminimized game
-saw that i had been killed
-asked why gaben had forsaken me

All joking aside, this game is incredible, and you shouldn't hesitate to buy it. It can be about as much fun as getting a vasectomy with a pair of rusty hedge clippers by a hobo in an alley in Detroit at times, but the feeling of jubilation you get when you finally kill a difficult boss or get past a difficult area (like the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ piece of ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ Shrine of Amana) is unbeatable by most other games.
You should also get Dark Souls 1, except the PC port is a piece of poop.
That's all I got.
Buy it.
Now.

reviewText: This game is absolutely fantastic. It's hard as hell, but thats the fun of it. When you die, you can usually tell that it was your own fault. Firm but fair. The combat is great and it's mechanics are well designed. The level design is great too, with many little secrets hidden around each area. when you explore, you are rewarded for it. I also like the mutliplayer features. teaming up to fight bosses is really fun, as is invading other players and killing them. You can join covenants, which are factions dedicated to a particular aspect of the game, such as PVP and co-op. These flesh out the multiplayer aspects a bit more. Best of all, it's a decent port this time. It runs at 60fps native, and doesnt look like a slideshow any more. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG's and is up for a challenge.

reviewText:
A sequel , that PC player deserved.

I have heard about the start trouble for some problem and I know it is not a good thing , but do not judge the game for having these problem, but the Developers. I did not have any problem with the PC version after the release.

The PC version is far better than the console version. 60 FPS, better textures and a great Network connection.
You can run this game with a mid-PC on High/Very High with stable 60 fps, which surprised me.
There are problems with the Keyboard and Mouse controls, but when you get used to it, it is not that bad.
But yeah, they should have worked on KB+M more. The atmosphere and the music fits perfectly in that game
and there are many places to explore. Some locations even remind you of the prequel.

Dark Souls 2 is a mix of Demon's and Dark Souls, which makes the gameplay so good.
The beginning of the game is very good for beginners of the Souls series, but when you are a Veteran , you can skip the tutorial. Most of the Boss fights are good, but I do not recall a great" fight. So you almost forget about most boss fights

reviewText:
I have to balance out the negative reviews here. If you look at all the negative reviews for this you'll realise that most people have put at least a hundred hours into the game.  I love this game- it's worth the 80 bucks i've put into it for the hours of enjoyment i've had out of it and i feel most people who have given this game a negative review would agree on that point.

This game is worth buying twice- i wish the added content was a available as a small priced DLC- i haven't given up hope that that will be the case. However if it's not- i'm going to pay another 80 bucks for this game come May- and if i get at least a good 30 hours of fun- and it's likely i'll get 10 times that number- i'll have had my money's worth and you will too!

It's an important caveat that an updated version is in the works- but i m still happy to recommend this version at this time- why wait at least 5 months to play this awesome game?




EDIT- all tthis being said here is my letter to bandai-namco

Hi there- just saying, i absolutely adore your Demon souls/Dark Souls IP and have loved every game. The support you have shown as publishers for these amazing titles has been pretty dismal though.

Please support these wonderful IP's more thoughtfully. People should still be purchasing and playing the first rendition of the Dark Souls game- particularly for PC. It should continue to be a lucrative title but you are not supporting it appropriately and it's downright ludicrous that you've punished the modder who has actually made this game worth purchasing for the PC- however there is no excuse for not appropriately supporting this game yourselves.

In regards to Dark Souls 2;  support and improvement have been much better and i have purchased the game on two systems and all DLC separately. Please tell me the new HD content will be available as a purchasable DLC and not as a standalone full priced game. If you do that you're officially strangling your cult following for these amazing games. If you really want to make it rain cash- support dark souls 1, re-release Demon Souls with HD content- get these awesome games out of the bargain bin- don't let them be largely broken and incompatible works of genius that went the way of the grave due to a lack of publisher support; get them back on the top shelf of gaming where they should be.

Thankyou.

PS Exclusive deals with consoles make baby jesus- and your fans- cry. Also- it relegates your games firmly to the past- you've dated your game to the console and limited the audience to the users of one meagre console- which is a really terrible idea. Ah- well- too late i guess :(

reviewText:
So I've just acquired 100% of the achievements to the game, and although it was totally unnecessary, I feel I'm qualified to write a review now.

First of all; I started the game and I finished the game with keyboard and mouse. The default keybindings I found pretty terrible to be honest, and the game using Xbox controller key prompts made it all the more frustrating. After having played with a controller and changing the keys to my liking though, I have to say that I couldn't bring myself to go back to the controller.

Dark Souls II has fairly decent graphics, but falls short of triple A releases. It makes up for that with a smooth 60 frames per second which is absolutely vital in a game like this which requires you to patiently learn enemies moves while dodging death by the breadth of a hair. Fortunately you don't need a beast of a PC to run it either, with my average (or below) set up of an AMD Radeon HD 6780 + four gigs of RAM I experienced maybe three or four frame drops through my ten characters.

The game itself is really quite challenging. Casual gamers I'd imagine would have a hell of a time trying to adapt and I'd highly reccommend searching for the hidden attributes in some stats and what they fully affect, while Hardcore gamers will have plenty of room to trip up as well. Don't fret if the game feels too intimidating, failing is a large part of every Souls players first experience, it's the ecstacy in beating the jerk after your tenth try for some sweet revenge and coming back later in the game when you're more experienced to take the time to torture them.

As far as Online Play goes... You'll find a lot of fantastic people willing to engage in jolly cooperation, but keep in mind that there are no rules in the Dark Souls universe, in a broken and decaying Kingdom it's every man for themselves and some people just want to watch the world burn.

reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 is a very unforgiving experience. Just imagine Demon Souls as the cute girl who liked playing with whips and gags. Dark Souls 2 is the professional dominatix who would ♥♥♥♥ that cute girl right in her ♥♥♥.

This game is really fun. I have never put so many hours into an RPG.

The array of weapons in this game is large. You can wield a Claymore all the way to a repeating crossbow. The way the weapons are made, you can win the hardest of boss battles with a broken mundane ladle.

On to infusions, a neat little feature. You can imbue your weapons and shields with a collection of elements such as lightning, fire, and magic. They will greatly affect the way your weapons dealout damage, and the way the weapons work.

The Leveling up system is magnificent. You can invest skill points into things such as strength to allow you to use bigger and badder weapons and to increase damage output. You can invest points into Intelligence, allowing you to use spells and Faioth to use Miracles (Not world peace). You can create intracte builds such as a Knight or a Dark Mage on Crack. You can level up all the way to Level 838. Which will pretty much cancel out the negative effects of Soul Memory.

Soul Memory is quite a contriversal feature. It cancels out the matchmaking system from Dark Souls 1, throwing out Soul Level matchmaking. Soul Memory is divided up into tiers. You can be Level 45, but losing souls constantly and forgeting to Level up; You can PvP with a guy who is Soul Level 345, and he's fully geared. It can also split up friends trying to play together. You can both be Soul Level 234, but one of you has 77mil soul memory and the other has 6.7million soul memory. The Soul Memory system is completely ignored in the BoB PvP arena.

Now onto Player interaction. So you're stuck on a hard boss and you're just about to give yourself a vasectomy. All of a sudden a bright white sign appears on the ground. Summon Xx_Pu$$y_D3STR0YER_xX". As he arises from the ground in a brilliant white sheen

column16: The dark areas don't seem too dark that you can barely see what is happening infront of you
column17:
No more Blighttown from DS1 :). Overall it is a much better port than DS1 ever was even with DSfix. As well as Controllers not being the only option you have a Keyboard and Mouse is just as fine a way of playing the game as any Controller is! Praise the Sun!

I've yet to come across any game breaking bugs or any sort of hacking (That i know of) Bar the lag and the hitbox issues when fighting other players i don't have a lot of bad things to say about this game. I feel a lot of the hatred it gets is from people who played Dark Souls 1 and loved it and can't quite get to grips with the second game changing a few of the core concepts of the original.

The Characters in the game have interested Dialogue and do help you out with little hints a long the way for if you do get lost. You WILL get lost and go to an area much harder than what you should currently be at
column18: everyone does it so don't worry
column19:
All the Souls games have had Zero Sense of direction i.e it won't hold your hand and show you where to go quite like other games but that's half the fun.

If Dark Souls 2 came out before DS1 i would still prefer Dark Souls 2 for its better overall polish. Dark Souls 1 was never meant to be a PC game and was ported in a rush. Which From Software can be blamed for because from Dark Souls 2 and what i've seen of Bloodborne their games can and do overall look well polished.

No doubt i'll get some stick for saying DS1 was never a Masterpiece but it had its really good times in PVP and most of its PvE but it had a lot of issues that really needed addressed before it was ever made available to the PC market.

If you like a game which allows you to slam your balls into a wall over and over again

reviewText:
This game is truly wonderful, there's a lot of hard practice within the game and you can't just always rely on one tactic to win. Every enemy has been balanced along with the weapons and armour to always give that feeling of struggle, no matter how high in strength you are. PVP however is where this game is let down, mainly because the players who play this game like to make use of the cheapest tactics they can manage in order to win. Here's just a list of what to expect if you try doing Dark Souls 2 PVP:

Channeler's trident with any magic buff and poison infusion while spamming heavy attack to drill hit you and just stack poison? Check.
Infinite HP hacks? Check. (I've encountered at least 46 different players doing this so far)
Poison/Bleed estoc to bypass shields? Check.
Infinite stagger caestus build? Check.
Prebuffing and then using poison fog/toxic mist/dark fog/acid surge as you are summoning in so you get poisoned/have your armour and rings broken before you can even act? Check. (watch out would be dragons, this happens to you a LOT)
Prebuffing and then trying to backstab you as you are summoning in? Check (Dragons again...)
Waiting right by where you appear and spamming fire tempest or other AoE spells so you have no time to act when you summon in? Check. (dragons especially)
Abusing rolls to ensure no form of magic will ever hit them? Check. (Oh yeah, if you roll? You can't get hit by most magic unless it's a flat out hit. Not a fun thing if you get forced into PVP and you're a caster of any form).

That's just a short list of the cheap tactics I've seen being put to use while I have played Dark Souls 2. Players will not try to play fair and as a result, it ruins the experience for the people who are trying to play the game fairly. Most even take PRIDE in this factor and you can find tons of builds to accompany these tactics so as to 'pwn maximum number of noobs' as one person put it.

I will complement Dark Souls 2 however as it has made co-operative play (especially with friends) much, MUCH better than Dark Souls 1. You get a name engraved ring you can buy that allows you to connect to players using the same 'god' that you choose using the ring. There's a large selection of gods and goddesses so you have little risk of being summoned by someone who you don't want to be summoned by. There's also two forms of aid you can do: Shades (which last a certain time and vanish when they've either killed so many enemies or have been there long enough, you can tell if a shade's about to vanish because they start turning black) and phantoms (Just like Dark Souls 1, they vanish when you beat a boss usually). A nice thing they've made sure to note is while there are areas where phantoms can't be summoned, shades can still be summoned in some of them, allowing for you to still recieve aid from your friends if you need it (and some areas you really DO need it.

For those travelling alone, From Software hasn't forgotten about you. Almost every single boss has a NPC phantom or two somewhere nearby that can aid you if you are unfortunate enough to have the dark souls 2 server lose connection or if you lose connection to steam. What's more, some of them have storylines that grant you their equipment if you accomplish them.

Overall, there's plenty of nice things in Dark Souls 2 that I would really want to praise. There's a vast array of weapons, armours and items to help you on your journey and it's possible to make all kinds of playthroughs (I've even seen someone playing a run as a character named after and tooled up exactly like Simon Belmont from castlevania. That was funny to play along with!).

If anything, it's Dark Souls 2's PVP that lets it down in the long run and a lot of the covenants make use of PVP to rank up so you are kind of forced to face it at some point if you want the most out of covenants... though thankfully you can switch covenants freely in Dark Souls 2, which is a god send.

There was one other thing that disappointed me though (and this is more a personal nitpick than anything else)... the weapons while vast and arrayed... well, it doesn't exactly have the same kind of fantastic variety that Dark Souls 1 had. I thought it was neat when I could get a sword made out of crystal or the dark sword from the darkwraiths (I was pleased the armour was back but COME ON FROM SOFT, why no sword to go with!?) which all had really unique designs and stood out. Granted, there are a few nice and unique weapons but I just feel it's lacking there. Who knows? Maybe the DLC coming out will provide us with some more really neat tools of destruction? I sure hope so!

Would I recommend Dark Souls 2? Yes, VERY MUCH YES I would recommend this game. But there are things that you need to be aware of when you pick this game up and I hope this review will help those who are considering this game for various reasons to consider before picking it up. From Software is making constant balance checks with this game so maybe they might see some of the problems and deal with them but in the meantime, thank you for reading my review and I hope it gave you all information about Dark Souls 2 that will help you decide to buy the game.

Good luck, and hope you're prepared to die all over again. You'll be doing it a lot.

reviewText:
Love this game. Just like Dark Souls and Demon Souls before that, this game is brutally hard. The new bosses, new enemies, new characters. (A couple are forgettable though) Overall, an excellent game.

There's more story here than in previous FS titles, however it's still abstract enough to weave your own tale from. Also, the option to postpone a NG+ is awesome, since you can use that time to finish off any optional bosses you may have missed.

Pros:
+ Excellent sound and design
+ Excellent soundtrack. The music is really good! Outdoes any of their previous work
+ 60 FPS is awesome. No need for mods to unlock it. The experience is awesome, even without modding the ♥♥♥♥ out of it
+ PVP duels. PVP is still here, but you can now dual people from your covinant. A really nice feature

Cons:
- Still has some crazy glitches
- Some bosses are way to predictable and offer no real challenge. (Thankfully just a few. The majority are still hard)
- Parry/Reposte and backstabs. WTF? Backstabs are still OK to do, but parrying is rediculous. I prefer DKS1 system better

All in all, if you're a Souls fan, this is a must own. The replay value alone is enough to satisfy your need for masochism. I can't recommend this game enough!

reviewText:
This is my review without playing DS1 before . At my first time play through,because of terrible port. I almost ditched this game but on a second thought, I gave it another try by overlooking bad port and poor graphic. This time I really enjoyed the game. I  played it till the end and still want to play more so I would like you guys to read my review first, you will understand why this game has a lot of lovers and haters at the same time, and whether this game suits your taste or not.

Let me start with the bad port first. As many negative reviewers said, this game has a abysmal console port EVER !. If you have controller, you will not have the issue. Nevertheless, if you have only keyboard + mouse, You will have to spend 1-2 hours learning how to play with keyboard. Even after you know how to do every moveset, you still have a delay. Anyway, you still can play this game with keyboard + mouse. Me too struggled at first but now totally fine.

Second, the Graphic is unacceptable if you compare to PC RPG game nowadays. So even without keyboard issue, this game cannot get perfect score. No zooming to the face when you talk to NPC, NPC mouth is shut. Character creation is bare bone. Begining cinematic is a lie. You will not see cinematic like that again in the game. The only cinematics left are seen when you fight a boss, which most of them are mediocre.

Third, there is a very little story in this game, or I could say this game has no story at all, no quest or whatever. You just have to put yourself through the end of the game, that's it. This game is pretty much like a hack&slash game if you ask me.

However, even with these very poor features, this game still has its huge merit, that is THE CHARISMA of the game. or in another word, THE CHALLENGE, which is very unique if it is compared with most RPG games in the market. EVERY TIME YOU DIE, THE GAME WILL PUNISH YOU, this concept adds the unique tense that I never had before in other games. Every death will decrease your maximum HP 5 - 10% per time and If you die again before getting to the spot that you just died, you will lose all your souls accumulated, which can be a huge loss since you have to use souls to up your lv and spend stuffs. Of course, you cannot save your game. This rule will force you focus on the game and be cautious to every corner, traps and enemy. I must survive ! I must not die" these are what you will chanting in your mind while playing the game. There are checkpoints (bonfire) available though

reviewText:
Although not as atmospheric as its pedecessor, Dark Souls 2 manages to streamline and balance gameplay, combat and its unique online aspect, further improving on the formula that Demons' Souls first introduced on PS3.

DS2 is a wonderful game, filled with challenges, secrets, a bazookaload of content, witty dark and often intentionally downplayed and obscured humor and tons of interesting if peculiar bits.

However, what first surprised me is that its world structure is reminescent of the series' pioneer title rather than going for tightly intertwined and natural flowing maps like the first Dark Souls had, also adding the possibility to warp between bonfires at your leisure from the very beginning.
Generally speaking, the DS2 areas generally blink" one after the other

Game was really hard at first, then I did what I consider the smart thing now.  I farmed souls to get better equipment.
For leveling, I'm really only leveling so far to get stats needed for equipment.  Working fine so far.
Still have trouble at times, but mainly just from enemies's tactics I don't know yet.

Haven't had anyone invade yet and has me somewhat glad, since I'm more of a soloist and co-op fan than pvp.

My opinion is that this game exceeded expectations.

reviewText:
This is my review without playing DS1 before . At my first time play through,because of terrible port. I almost ditched this game but on a second thought, I gave it another try by overlooking bad port and poor graphic. This time I really enjoyed the game. I  played it till the end and still want to play more so I would like you guys to read my review first, you will understand why this game has a lot of lovers and haters at the same time, and whether this game suits your taste or not.

Let me start with the bad port first. As many negative reviewers said, this game has a abysmal console port EVER !. If you have controller, you will not have the issue. Nevertheless, if you have only keyboard + mouse, You will have to spend 1-2 hours learning how to play with keyboard. Even after you know how to do every moveset, you still have a delay. Anyway, you still can play this game with keyboard + mouse. Me too struggled at first but now totally fine.

Second, the Graphic is unacceptable if you compare to PC RPG game nowadays. So even without keyboard issue, this game cannot get perfect score. No zooming to the face when you talk to NPC, NPC mouth is shut. Character creation is bare bone. Begining cinematic is a lie. You will not see cinematic like that again in the game. The only cinematics left are seen when you fight a boss, which most of them are mediocre.

Third, there is a very little story in this game, or I could say this game has no story at all, no quest or whatever. You just have to put yourself through the end of the game, that's it. This game is pretty much like a hack&slash game if you ask me.

However, even with these very poor features, this game still has its huge merit, that is THE CHARISMA of the game. or in another word, THE CHALLENGE, which is very unique if it is compared with most RPG games in the market. EVERY TIME YOU DIE, THE GAME WILL PUNISH YOU, this concept adds the unique tense that I never had before in other games. Every death will decrease your maximum HP 5 - 10% per time and If you die again before getting to the spot that you just died, you will lose all your souls accumulated, which can be a huge loss since you have to use souls to up your lv and spend stuffs. Of course, you cannot save your game. This rule will force you focus on the game and be cautious to every corner, traps and enemy. I must survive ! I must not die" these are what you will chanting in your mind while playing the game. There are checkpoints (bonfire) available though

reviewText:
After playing a good chunk already on PS3, I thought I would give the PC version a quick run and see how well it performed. Now this will pretty much be a cheesy pros and cons list to make it relatively fast.

Pros:
-Bonfire travel is no longer limited to after one point in the game
-Life gems comebined with estus are REAL nice considering how much more valuable estus are in this game
-LOTS of content
-Relatively smooth gameplay/combat
-Variety of locations and enemies
-Scarce on the surface but rewards those who explore
-Story might be more approachable but plenty of hidden lore
-Lots of Dark Souls references and even some Demon's Souls references.
-PVP is relatively fine, a lot smoother than Dark Souls I'll say that much
-Way better PC port this time around
-Nice smooth start for beginners but still offer the challenges veterans seek
-Ways to make the game harder
-Bonfire Asthetics
-Variety of playstyles

Cons:
-Hitboxes go out of wack every now and then
-F***ING SOUL MEMORY
-Staggering is either way too easy on most enemies and you also stagger fairly easy
-Boss difficulty and spread feels inconsistent
-A few levels feel poorly designed
-Game feels a bit more linear near Drangleic Castle
-Method of obtaining certain gear


Pretty much this game is Demon's Souls with a Dark Souls paint but still a solid game that a Souls fan or intersted player should pick up.


**UPDATED NOTE THAT I FORGOT TO INCLUDE**
While you can use a keyboard and mouse, it is still a pain in the ♥♥♥ even though you can tell the controls are more functional. Even after rebinding you will still find the controller superior.

reviewText:
I'm in a love/hate relationship with this game. The content of the game itself is amazing, I love it as much as Demon's Souls and Dark Souls, but the technical issues that comes with it makes me want to strangle and drown it in a bathtub... and then become Herbert West and attempt to revive it.

I love playing around with different characters, killing bosses over and over, engaging in jolly co-operation and all that, but every now and then, the game will give you the finger with its glitchy-at-best mechanics.

Phantom hitboxes, cross-region restriction not actually working (in a couple hours I invaded / was invaded by a bunch of koreans, chinese and americans, and only 1 European (yes, I am in Europe)), lagstabs left and right (the only thing it does better than Dark Souls 1 with online play as opposed to GFWL is being able to connect to others, the ridiculous lag is still present because the cross-region option does not work for ♥♥♥♥), button presses suddenly refusing to register (with and without a controller), disconnect messages are more common than successful invasions, RNG jumping mechanics (you either jump short distance or long distance, completely inconsistent, annoying for when you shortjump 7 times in a row to get the ember, will quite often also tell speedrunners to go ♥♥♥♥ themselves), animations locking in place rendering your character unable to do anything until you accept your fate and die. The list goes on and on.

I think I might have stockholm syndrome.

reviewText:
Honest Review from an honest PC gamer. Skip to the bottom if TL;DT for verdict.

I've been a Souls fan ever since Demon's Souls, which by the way is one of my all time favorite games.
Dark Souls II has for me been both joy and misfortune. I am of course speaking of the amazing lighting and graphics shown at the 2013 E3 Demo's of the game. I understand why From had to downscale the game in such a drastic way in order for their game to be able to run on consoles, but I don't think this goes for PC.
Being the all-time PC masterrace gamer I am, I too, enjoy graphics and while story and gameplay is of course what weighs the most in my opinion, graphic matters a lot.
I bought DkS II for console 14th of May, and I was heavily dissapointed with the resolution and framerate. It's playable, and yes, somewhat enjoyable but it doesn't do justice for a game when it's played @ 30 FPS and 720p.
This has however been addressed" in the PC version
hoursPlayed: mine being 2560x1440p\nand clearly higher resolution texture work.\nIt is however sad to say that the E3 Demo lighting is gone. Which is a downer
voteText: but. Hey.\n\nOn the contrary Mod God Durante has already made possible for Texture modding
helpfulPercent: as well as given guides for better lighting using Nvidia Inspector
votesHelpful: and SweetFX. Let me tell you
votesTotal: the SweetFX profile does wonders
votesFunny: and I highly recommend that all of you PC gamers out there try this out. Here's a SweetFX profile made by K-putt: http://sfx.thelazy.net/games/preset/1568/\n\nBesides the "need" for better lighting

Pros
- 60 FPS as opposed to 30 on console.
- Native resolution (Which ever your screen is)
- Higher resolution texture's as opposed to console.
- No GFWL. This game use Steam.
- 4 to 5 second loading time when traveling/teleporting as opposed to 15 to 20+ on Console.
- Controls feel great on controller
- Playable with Mouse&Keyboard combo. It works just fine

reviewText:
So much negativity on these forums about this game... I just don't understand it...
60+ hours, day one purchase, completed, NG+ at the moment...
No bugs, glitches, online worked fine, maybe I was one of the lucky ones?
Thrilling, exciting (don't get me wrong it's not as good as DS1) - it lacks the 'love' of its prequels...
BUT
Still amazing...
Still the DS we all know and love...
And all those saying 'rubbish port' - it's nonsense - sharp at 1080p - I played on 60 TV with wireless Xbox controller (why you'd even contemplate playing with mouse / keyboard is beyond me for a game like this...)
It's brilliant.
Worth every penny and long may the franchise continue (as long as it gets a bit more 'original' along the way!)

WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? PREPARE TO DIE!

EDIT: 80+ hours done (many offline to avoid invasions!) and NG+ complete... what a great game
date: don't get me wrong it has many flaws like its predecessors
recommended: but still a worth entry in the series...I can finally burn this game on the bonfire at Majula... phew... exhausted but very happy...\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OTB0qum_t6o&list=UUy7kWBkzBwT1jsz7biD4rVg"

reviewText:
I really tried to like DS2, it was the first souls game i tried and i didn't liked it at all the first time; after I played [and fell in love with] DS1 i pushed myself to retry DS2, but it's no use.

DS2 is a mess, the levels are not connected in a huge environment as in the first game, most of the bosses are just regular enemies x5-20 in a small room trying to give the illusion of challenge when in fact makes it unfair as you cannot keep an eye at all of them at the same time.

There is not a single well developed NPC, i started two NG and almost made it to the end on both runs and can't remember ONE name, because they have no impact on the run, they are not interesting, they are just so boring.

The same can be said about the stages, they're way too linear and have nothing that makes them special, they try to force Majula as an interesting location by making EVERY important merchant/mage/level booster/npc be there, but it has nothing of interest, and i don't even know how that is posible when the FIre link Shrine of DS1 is more interesting and that's just a half blown castle.

To sum up, play DS1 and DS3, don't waste your money on this one.

reviewText:
I was gifted the first game about a year ago and it quickly went from completely unknown to me to being one of the best games I've ever played.

This game contains all the things that made the last one great, along with an entirely new set of areas, hundreds of new weapons, armor, and spells, and nine new covenants (which are most usually a sort of player faction in pvp).

There are also ~30 bosses, each with a different kind of design and backstory. Speaking of the story: it is one of the most interesting ways to present one. Most of the story is uncovered through such simple things as loot placement, area design, and item descriptions. NPC dialogue shouldn't be glossed over either: it can be easily skipped over or ignored, but it usually contains important (or sometimes blatant) hints towards your next objective or to the lore itself.

The level design is still incredibly well done. You are almost always capable of choosing between 2-4 choices at a time when deciding where to go next. This non-linear model is contrasted against the more linear design of the individual levels, which allows them to fine tune the path through the area for the best gameplay experience.

The combat itself is quite good as well. All actions deduct from a regenerative stamina bar, which means you must be strategic in order to plan out your actions. This usually means that the PvP involves exploiting mistakes that your opponent makes. The wide variety of weapons (anything from a katana to a scythe is available, with multiple weapons usually taking up each type of weapon moveset) allows for some specialization in a fight, as well as the four different branches of magic.

Online play involves PvP or co-op, where you are capable of either helping someone else along through their game as a phantom, or invading their world as a dark spirit in order to fight them. Covanants alter these two main components of multiplayer into many different forms.

Many of these features I've described may seem like it should be a standard feature of a game, but I've found that at least some of these can be done away with or poorly executed in many games.

One notable detriment is that the default keyboard/mouse controls are quite bad. However, they can easily be rebound to a more familiar layout in-game.

Features like NG+, multiplayer, and completionism can make this game's replayability last fo days yo.

21394567/21394567 would recommend

reviewText: For those who haven't played a Souls game, you are missing out. Gameplay that doesn't worry about caterring to a casual crowd but instead changes the way you look at and play games makes this series unique among others in the action rpg genre. That being said, Dark Souls 2 is a farcry from what it was in Demon's souls and Dark souls in terms of care and attention to detail. While the core of Dark Souls 2 is the same, it feels largely more artificial and self aware. Difficulty was always present in the series, but not as a marketing gimmick, rather a tool to immerse and amuse the players in ways not done before. These games never hold your hand, but make you adapt and increase in skill through trial and error. Dark Souls 2 feels too much like an attempt to feel difficult, to the point where some bosses and areas are just ridiculous. Approximately half of the bosses are just let's throw as many enemies into one room as possible" and have multiple copies or enemies pot shotting you. While the older games did this
date: it was in small doses. That is not to say its a bad game
recommended: in fact its very good. Graphics are quite nice and some enviornments are very well done. Weapons are still as fun to use and unique to eachother that allow every player to tackle the game differently. Nobody wants to feel like all challenge and reward are pointless and absent. DS 2 definitely delievers a quality challenge and rewards patience and skill. Just be warned
hoursPlayed: Dark Souls 2 is not the defining chapter in the Souls Series. Give it a try
voteText: and then experience the older titles to get the full experience."

reviewText:
“so that they know that is a totally new game, to be able[sic] have a whole new set of challenges and to curse and throw the controller at the screen.” - Daniel Markoff, localization producer at Bandai Namco Games.

For everything Dark Souls II does right, it does something equally wrong.

You now have a dedicated jump button so jumps are now tiny hops.

All players are always online to reduce hacking so now you can never play in offline mode.

You can now run up/down ladders so pressing B will make you jump off a ladder usually killing you.

Weapons auto repair at bonfires so weapon durability very rapidly decays.

Spell casting is faster and now scales with attunement so you get less casts per spell unless you level attunement.

I could easily go on but the bottom line is this; Dark Souls 2 is the sequel to Dark Souls 1 so chances are you played the first game and you know what you are signing up for anyway.

I could and should rate this game down but if you knew nothing about this game you probabaly wouldn't be buying it anyway and if you are reading this review then you probabaly played the first game in which case this almost is the same god-awful, fustrating and repetitive experience that you love except they now swarm you with enemies instead, so go ahead and buy it.

Because I know you like to cut yourself at night, their will be a patch soon that you have to pay for regardless of if you bought this game and it's season pass and/or all the DLC.

The DirectX9 version of Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin will sell for $40, while the DirectX11 version will be $50. If you already own Dark Souls II on Steam, you can upgrade to the DirectX11 edition of Scholar (since the current version is DX9) for $30; if you own Dark Souls II and all the DLC, you can upgrade to the DX11 version for $20.

Got it? I hope so, because we're not done yet. The DX9 and DX11 versions will have separate pages in the Steam store, so you'll want to be careful about which one you buy to ensure that you don't either shortchange yourself, or end up with a version you can't run. Furthermore, the two versions of the game are not compatible for multiplayer action: If you upgrade to the DX11 version and all your friends stick with the original DX9 release, you'll be playing without them

reviewText:
I sank all my time in the original dark souls, and now i will sink all my time once more into this new epic of a game. Everything in this universe we came to call dark souls, is a grim dark, lushious and gothic setting of a dying world, and this is no different in dark souls 2. From the tiniest details to vast landscapes, the scenery once again amazes me, with enough innovation to come up with new areas while still keeping that oldv grimdark feeling dark souls 1 imposed on you.

There are not enough words to express how much i fell in love with this series all over again. The brutal, punishing nature forces one to hone their skills and become better players, learning from every mistake they make, overcoming insurmountable obstacles and all done in such a way that it's fair. It's not crippling rage that grips you when you make a mistake, but a sense of enlightenment, as you now know what that particular scenario will do to you. You overcome and adapt anything the game throws at you in due time and looking back you will find yourself wondering why the start of this adventure was so harsh. This is why dark souls is magic and will go down in history for that exact concept.

This game deserves all my money and all my time, and i highly reccomend it to everyone and their unborn children.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Most games reward you, or congratulate you in some positive way when you defeat the final boss.
Instead, Dark Souls 2 (much like the other souls games) throws out a big old kick in the shins, and rewards you with the option to start again, with 2x more nemies, 2x more health on enemies, and 2x more damage coming from the enemies.

You can kill men, women, spiders, giants, massive dragons, 'Balrog' from LOTR, and even little piglets (assuming they dont kill you first). Yet, you cannot however, even manage to put a scar on a talking cat that sells rings for some reason.

You will cry a little, maybe even contemplate turning he game off and having a rest, but no matter how much you want to, you are still going to spend 4 hours just trying to kill the Smelter Demon, only to have the ability to kill in in 1/2 attempts once you kill him for the first time ever.

And if the game itself doesnt kill you, you will probably get invaded by a player wearing rocks, and an onion head that is wielding a 1000m long katana somehow described as a washing pole, and throwing magic at you using a frog stuck on a stick.

11/10, would visit psychiatrist again
