reviewText:
Game: Dark Souls II
Score: 8/10
Recommended? Yes, but not THIS version
Worth a buy at full price? No, buy Scholar of the First Sin, instead

WARNING: BUY SCHOLAR OF THE FIRST SIN, NOT THIS VERSION

The new version of this game came out that uses DX11 graphics is bundled with all of the DLC. Saves from this version of the game do NOT carry over. Do NOT buy this version unless you want to spend more money and waste time.

Now that that's out of the way, here's for the real review.

Dark Souls II, more challenging than the first, still is very enjoyable. The game still retains difficult enough combat to be considered a souls game, and if you've played the first game, you will for sure enjoy this one.

For those of you new to the series, I would recommend you pick up a copy of the first game while you wait for Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin to be released. It will be a good gauge of whether or not you will like this game, and it is only $20 instead of $40.

Gameplay wise, the game is much smoother. 60fps and 1080p is a HUGE improvement. Movement feels much more fluid and controls more responsive.

Creativity wise, the game is OKAY. It is not as bad as many claim it to be; that said I still think the first game holds much more value in creative boss/enemy design and lore, as far as the story goes. The majority of bosses in this game are some variant of humanoid in armor
date:
and with a friend, can be easily conquered.

There are many more weapons and armor in this game than in the first, which I also consider a nice touch. It's fun being able to swap looks whenever you decide to change things up.

In PVP/Coop, the game is somewhat unbalanced. Rather than basing matchmaking on soul level (the level of your character based on the attributes you choose to upgrade), the game bases matchmaking on soul MEMORY, the total number of souls collected. This makes for fights where your opponent may have much, much higher/lower stats than you, depending on how they spent their souls collected overtime.

That said, I haven't seen nearly as many hackers/cheaters/glitchers as in the first game. Many players have a finite amount of health and can be beaten if fought correctly.

Conclusion:
I recommend this game to others as a good entry in the souls series. However, for the love of all that is good in this world, DO NOT BUY THIS VERSION OF THE GAME. Go grab the remastered edition, Scholar of the First Sin, instead.

reviewText: Dark souls, oh my dear Dark Souls. How little i initially cared about you. As a hardcore PC gamer im disgusted by the very idea of even holding onto a controller, let alone actually play a game with one. Even after that the horrible PC port actually turned me off Dark Souls 1 completely. But the idea of the Souls games always intrigued me. I was one of the few people who actually enjoyed some of those I wanna be the guy" Games. In my mind they were challenging
date: but they were a lot about recollection and planning ahead.\n\nBut alas
recommended:
i didn't play the original Dark Souls. And after the huge disappointment that was Lords of the ♥♥♥♥ers i was kind of turned away from everything Souls-like for a decent amount of time.

But then i noticed Dark Souls 2 was on sale.

Now if you're like me you're always worried whenever you buy a game off of a sale. Cause you never really know what the hell you're getting into. But my fear was increased tenfold when i was booting up Dark Souls 2 for the first time
hoursPlayed:
because i had of course experienced the nightmare that had been Dark Souls on PC. So imagine my very happy self when once i had watched the opening cutscene and got to walk around it happened without a hitch. I was able to walk briskly around like the happiest little puppy in the daycare.

That was when i was greeted by the intro.

Look From Software

votesTotal: seen a lets play of Dark souls 1. So i knew dodging was an essential part of its combat.\n\nNow
votesFunny: after i had slain my assailant i briskly moved onwards through the tunnels of Things Betwixt
commentsCount: fighting off more undead soldiers as i went along until i came to a hole in the road. I went into my controls to find out what the jump button was
column16: and saw it was bound to F. So i ran forward and immediately fell down because i didn't know how to jump properly.\n\nI then respawned and found to my dismay that my previously handsome knight had somehow caught the Plague
column17: and had therefore turned a very disgusting shade of green. I then also saw that my max health had gone down.\n\nNow
column18: this is a mechanic i don't really like. Cause a lot of the bosses and the areas leading up to them are very much dependent on trying a lot of times to get the hang of their movement and attack patterns. This becomes harder when you're actively punished for your death in a manner that can stick with you for a while.\n\nBut that doesn't deter from the awesome combat system though! Every single little bit of Dark Souls seems to be built around the combat. Every single boss is combat focused
column19: when you explore the inevitable thing thats going to be in the way of your progress is enemies that you almost always have to fight
column20: And all of your stat building and upgrades are inevitably going to be focused on fighting enemies. It is very good then
column21: that the combat system is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. It has this real weight to it that encourages timing and precision. It rewards patience and punished rash decisions. A lot of times the mentality of "Just one more hit
column22:
can either land you a close victory or a humiliating defeat.

The exploration is also nice. With plenty of hidden areas to find if you're willing to stray off the beat and path.

All in all this game is great, and while i dont condone the practice of making an HD remaster of it this soon (This being the upcoming redux version From Software are planning) This game is still amazing. Buy it if you can't wait, get the hd remaster once it comes out in the other case.

reviewText: SPOILERS AHEAD: One of, if not, the best game I have ever played. It is detailed and brilliant in so many ways. It provides nerve racking experiences aslong with a side of endless frustration, and rage inducing anger. But without that, it wouldn't be a Souls game. The strongest points of the game are its story, which is never really fully explained in the game itself, and how unique the game is and the experiences it gives you. From seeing the character you have worked along side for hours and hours, finally take his place on the Throne of Want. And seeing the once been towering ex-king of Drangleic walking slowly in repeated patterns in the god forsaken Undead Crpyt. From the struggle to beat the last giant, to finding that set of armour you want, to taking your place on the throne. This is a game that you build your own story with, and have a hell of a lot of fun doing it. I am in love with every nook and cranny of this game. 10/10 extremely recommend it.

reviewText:
I'm no professional reviewer, but this game deserves all the recommendations I can give.  This game is one of the best RPG's I've ever played, it has a very dark storyline that you actually have to discover and deduce instead of having it explained through cutscenes.  Each item connects to Drangleic or possibly to what existed before Drangleic.  The combat system is phenomenal, with a variety of attack patterns.  Besides the occasional hit box flaw, the combat is solid, and when you die (which happens many, many times) usually its just because of a dodge instead of a block or another fixable solution for the next time you face the enemy or trap.

Another great mechanic is the game's innovative multiplayer, although being killed by a PVP oriented player is a little annoying, the invasion into your game works flawlessly to just create another obstacle to overcome.  The arena mode lets all the PVP players test their builds or gloat about them, and the Co-op is wonderful for anyone needing a little help from friends on an area or two.

Even though the PC controls aren't the best, From did a good job on the port and as long as a controller is used there's definitely no difficulty playing this game.

While this is a very challenging game, it's also very rewarding and were I not so busy my time on this game would easily be quadrupled, definitely recommended for anyone who wants a challenging, rewarding RPG with some deep, dark lore.

reviewText:
A week before Dark Souls II's release date, I picked up Dark Souls I to prepare myself for the sequel. Dark Souls is now one of my favorite games of all time, and is one of the best RPGs out there right now. I poured hour after hour into that game. What makes Dark Souls so good? The world is beautiful, the atmosphere is incredible, the combat is smooth and challenging, the bosses are intimidating, the lore is amazing, but overall, it's rewarding. When you finally defeat a boss, you get an incredible sense of accomplishment. Every boss is incredible. The story-telling is amazing, in that there IS not story-telling. You don't get 10 minute cutscenes stuffing the story in your face. You get the story from your surroundings, from item descriptions, from lines that the NPC's say. The community pieces it all together and you get a beautiful story with lots of detail. The world felt connected; there were more than just one way to get to a location, and the game forced you to travel on your feet. Later in the game you get the ability to fast travel between bonfires which is awesome because by the time you learn the ability to do so, the world is huge and it would take forever to walk the whole way from A to B, but before you learn the ability there is no need for it. Also bonfires were few, so getting to one gave you this incredible sense of accomplishment. The world mattered.

Now enough about Dark Souls, let's talk about Dark Souls II, and why it was a disappointment. I'll just list all of my complaints I had with the game. I'll start with who made Dark Souls II. The director for Demon Souls and Dark Souls is NOT the same director for Dark Souls II. It's a different person, which explains a lot of things.

Let's talk about the bosses. They were a HUGE disappointment. They were easier than typical mobs in the first Dark Souls... For almost all the bosses, the typical strategy for killing the boss was: strafe, hit legs a couple times, dodge, repeat. A lot of the bosses were just copy and paste of bosses from the first Dark Souls. One was a literal copy and paste of Ornstein, and the rat boss you fight is just Sif in rat form. The final boss was a joke; it was one of the easiest bosses in the entire game. The final boss of the first Dark Souls was incredible! The beautiful music gave me such a chill during the fight. Dark Souls gave me an incredible feeling of accomplishment when YOU DEFEATED a boss (dark souls joke lol), and I got a different incredible feeling with Dark Souls II bosses; boredom.

Bonfires are EVERYWHERE, and I... mean... everywhere... They are scattered all over the damn game it's rediculous, and you can teleport between bonfires right from the start! There's a section of the game where you walk out of a dungeon and appear in what looks like a fallen city, filled with giant warriors. You walk accross the bridge, and you see a bonfire to your right. Awesome! Checkpoint! moving on. You kill about 5 of the giants, and you walk down some stairs and see a fog gate. You pass through, and a bossfight happens. Defeat the boss, and there's a bonfire up above. Another bonfire? That was quick. backtrack a bit, go up a drawbridge, defeat another boss, and there's a third bonfire down some stairs... This is all within 2 minutes of eachother. You can literally see one of the bonfires from another bonfire...

The NPCs are next. This will contain spoilers for the NPC's in Dark Souls I and II, so if you don't wanna know what happens to them, don't read...... ok moving on. The NPCs in DS had personality. Each one of them was different, and each one of them did something. The lore in DS was incredible, and each NPC was tied to it in some way, and each one had an interesting back story to them. There is a location in DS where most of the NPCs go when you find/save them, but as you progress through the game, they leave, and eventually, you find them... hollowed. and they turn on you. and try to kill you. Your friend who has been with you from the beginning, or your trainer who has taught you spells, or just a clumsy friend you found on your journey, they all die, and you are forced to kill them or you may die as well. 1 or 2 live, but only with your help. This adds to the feel of the game that nothing and nowhere is safe, and you will miss each NPC that dies, because you liked those guys, they were your friends. In DSII, NPCs have no personality, and I didn't care about any of them. If you find one on your journey, and you exhaust their dialogue, they will end up in the central hub area, where they NEVER LEAVE. They sit in that ONE area, never moving, and using the same 2 or 3 lines of dialogue whenever you talk to them... OH I HAD GIVEN YOU UP FOR DEAD gets old after the 2nd time I hear it, let alone after the 300th... they have 0 personality... One or two give you a sob story about how their life is hard, but it was hard to care about them at all.

Also, the mob placement... the mob placement is just randomized nonsense. Dark Souls at least put thought into where they placed enemies. The placement of enemines in II makes no sense, they're just kind of thrown into the game with zero thought.

The combat suuuuucks. At least for PVP, the combat is disgusting, and is in no way fun at all. The dodge roll is broken in this game. Rolling will save you from literally anything in this game, but only if you've thrown a ton of points into ADP. Don't have ADP? Have fun dying every two seconds. If you DO have lots of it, you're essentially a god. A lighting bolt coming at your face? roll! a sword about to cut you in half? roll! Being enveloped in a poisonous cloud? ROLL! I was challening a lighting spear and was prepairing to throw it at an enemy, and the enemy ran at me. At the last second, he rolled, but he rolled towards me. But by the time he rolled, he was already right in front of me, so he basically just rolled in place. The lighting bolt passed RIGHT THROUGH HIM! It pierced his torso and went right through him. Rolling should NOT make you invulnerable to everything, but IT DOOOOES, which is rediculously stupid. I'm not kidding when I say, if you are about to take damage from any source, press the roll button and you'll be k. Even if you don't include rolling among the problems with the combat, there are still lots more. Back stabbing is so weak in this game and just doen't work half the time, parrying feels horrible and unresponsive, and sometimes weapons will forget how long they are, and you will get stabbed from 20 feet away or you WONT get stabbed from 2 inches. The combat is clunky at best. Magic is broken. Not overpowered broken, but literally broken. You can be killed in one shot by magic, and there are so many stupid spells that have odd or nonexistant hitboxes (Lighting spears sometimes hit when they were fired in the opposite direction, or just no where near you) that you would THINK that it is overpowered. but it is also underpowered as well, because you just have to press the roll button as a soul spear pierces your heart and you'll be juuuust fine.

The atmosphere is nonexistant. you have the ability to warp from the beginning of the game, which takes away from the feel of the game. Also, there are places in the game that, once you pass through it, you may never come back to it again. Even in the late game of Dark Souls I would find myself going back to the beginning places, but in this game there is no need.

The problem I have with Dark Souls II is that... basically it's just not a real Souls game. If you don't compare it to any of the other Souls games, than Dark Souls II would be an mediocre game with a few problems. But if you DO compare it to any of the other Souls games, then Dark Souls II would be a horrible game with a lot of problems.

Every time I open this game up, thinking I was a bit too harsh, thinking that maybe there is a good game somewhere in this ♥♥♥♥, I become disappointed. Every single time.

reviewText: Did you like Dark Souls 1? You thought it was a rad game despite its pretty numerous flaws? reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 has an undeniable charm to it. The game is squarely aimed at a younger demographic with cuddly Undead that inhabit the land and cartoonish character-style and voices. Yet, the game design hits at something that can't be outgrown: the joy of discovery. That is, perhaps, the best way to describe From Softwares new gem.

Dark Souls 2 also culls from so many different ideas that it is hard to succfinctly explain what the point of the game is. The Chink developer's elaborately woven and complex endeavor brings great depth to the normally pallid kid genre, and that's part of what makes Dark Souls 2 such a great game. Despite ample room for improvement, this is easily one of the best titles, if not the best, From Software game since The Adventures of Cookie & Cream.

Part The Sims, part Animal Crossing and part Skyrim Difficulty AND part Rocko's Quest, Dark Souls 2 stands alone as a deep and engaging title on PC, fully accessible to people of all ages. To describe the game, we'll start from the beginning. The game kicks off by providing you with a ♥♥♥♥-riddled Corpse and tasks you with shaping the land using a sword. The point? To attract undead ♥♥♥♥ heads, each with chuckle-inducing names that are all candy and sweet-themed. Like real-life dead people, these undead have preferences for what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ they want to ♥♥♥♥ on.

All and all Dark Souls 2 gets my bad ♥♥♥ seal of APPROVAL!!!! making this one of the worst games ive played to date 6/10 Sub-par.

reviewerDisplayName: T H R I L L H O U S E
reviewText:
I give it 6/10.

If you're like me, and you adored Dark Souls 1, you are probably going to be disappointed by this game.

It's a mostly regurgitated mess with bland level design, bland enemies, bland bosses, bland combat variety, and absolutely zero of the magnificent atmosphere that got my ♥♥♥♥ hard with DS1.

Maybe it's all a matter of taste, but I played around 20 hours and defeated several bosses and not ♥♥♥♥ing once did I feel any sort of sense of accomplishment or excitement. I felt absolutely nothing but a tiny seed of disappointment planted after I swept through the forest of undeads level and defeated the last giant that only grew with time. I quit playing this after 10 hours or so and went back to DS1 to see if maybe it is very similar and I've just become a cynical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but nay, I still enjoy the everloving ♥♥♥♥ out of DS1 and put a good 20 hours into it before unehthusiastically dragging myself back to the bowl of plain grits that is DS2.

I tried to like this game, I wanted nothing more than to enjoy it like I did its predecessor, I wanted to love it. But no matter how much I let slide, how much I just marked up as 'different' instead of downgraded, I just couldn't enjoy this game.

It is a downgrade.

It is nothing but a 'Call of Duty' style sequel that has none of the magic you fell in love with, it is, and I apologize for the pun, soulless. And if you want to kid yourself into liking it because you just want another ♥♥♥♥ing dark souls game, I beseech of you, cease such blind actoins. If we praise this game out of blind nostalgia boners, they are going to vomit up another bland mess of uninspired bile for DS3.

TL;DR: I don't like it. It isn't a true sequel, it isn't even a good effort. To each his own, but mine is heartbreaking disappointment.

Now lets get to the gameplay, which realy lets me get angry and sad.

Angry because the best (swearword of your choice) way to kill 95% of your enemies is to use a ranged weapon (bows, crossbows magic stuff) or circling around them for 10 minutes until they fail to hit your shield!
Angry because Hitboxes (in wich they hit YOU!) and attacks of Bosses doesent make sense, you cant dodge most of them and some of them kills you allmost instandly, pointles how much armor you are using, most enemies kill you with 2-3 hits (doesent matter how small or big the enemies are). Also the windows between hughe enemies combos is that small, that you will be luky to get as least one hit. (if not unsing ranged weapons)

Angry because poise doesent work the same way as in DSI. You can have the highest poise possible an one hit with a (swearword of your choice) Sword ist enough to interupt the swing of your 200 kg Hammer swing or any other activity.

Angry because i need a stat for drinking my estus flask an doge an enemies attack properly (what doesent work in most cases)

Angry  because 90 % of your enemies will be huge (you 2-5 times) humanoids like:
tall knights, taller golden knights, giant knights, other giant knights, taller giant knights, lions with axes and shileds, giants  who shot magic with goblins(?) on their back, elephat giants with halberds, fatty guys with giant scythes, blue skinned guy with spears. huge pyromats with machetes on a long stick, giant hippos who will chew you to death immediatly, as well as skinny long armours with very long hammers and shields, tall witches and allmost every boss in the game.

Angry because they all play the same way, circiling around and bla....

Im angry because i cant do a fast roll!

And im getting sad when i realize that all this was way better in DS I !

Better do as i said first...

reviewText:
Dark Souls is definitely a game of great difficulty for a player who is not well prepared or familiar with the game. The game offers a very interesting storyline as well as an addictive urge to come back for more.

Well in all honesty, most of your first playthrough of the game will be spent screaming and raging at the countless amount of deaths you'll be facing, as death is inevitable with this game. Dark Souls isn't all that difficult once you become familiar with the games concepts and item locations, but either way it can still provide you with a decent challenge!

The game overall was a beautiful creation and it deserves all the praise and reputation it has. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who awaits a challenge and has the time to sink a decent amount of hours into it!

reviewText:
I was extremely excited to play this game due to it getting a LOT of love on the internet among hardcore gamers.

Unfortunately, this is easily the laziest port that I have ever touched in twenty years of gaming. The control displays (when you find actions to interact with the environment) are built for an Xbox 360 controller. The PC controls are designed poorly, so poorly in fact that I found myself looking online for better options for re-binding them that were designed by a human being rather than whatever twenty fingered alien completed this port in a bar on Tatooine.

Incredibly, the PC controls are so badly designed and overly complex that re-binding it becomes a kind of sudoku/puzzle game, because any change to one key inevitably overrides another action key that was already used for. Even the options menu to change key bindings uses the same dastardly Xbox 360 button displays - this goes beyond ridiculous, and would not have been excusable ten years ago, let alone in 2014.

While I appreciate that buying an Xbox 360 controller fixes many of these issues, the one way you can guarantee you will anger your consumers is by selling a product that requires a peripheral and not advertising how important this peripheral is to being able to genuinely play the game. There are more than enough third person action games that you can play perfectly well on a keyboard and mouse, and this port was more than lazy, it was an insult to its consumers. Fans who defend the game on the basis that you should have a 360 controller anyway for other games"
date: actually: no. A good consumer would never support a bad port no matter how much you like the game at its core
hoursPlayed: you are nothing but a slave doing a company's PR work for it.\n\nThe atmosphere and story of this game seem good and the graphics

Dark Souls II remains nothing more than a pretty picture until I go pay MicroSoft for their (in my opinion) crappy controller.\n\nI have also seen from recent remarks on the reviews page that a new

reviewText:
HUGE EDIT: Killed the Ancient Dragon before talking to him. Didn't drop ashen heart. Character is now locked and 140 hours of play wasted. THE FACT THIS IS A THING REALLY TICKS ME OFF.

I just can't recommend this game. I am a fan of Souls, I even played DeS until I got three characters to 712, a third to 650, and a fourth to 475, without using an exploit. I didn't get a whole out of DaS1, but it was still a very fun game and even felt innovative with what it was doing with DeS's foundation.

DaS2 is pretty broken. it feels a lot like it's ♥♥♥♥-riding Demon's while not quite understanding what made Demon's good. If I had to guess, I would say that From is just obligated to make hard games. DaS2 is very easy to cheese every enemy, while if you are brave enough to play normally; you'd quickly find that (at least on the PC version), enemies can do some real bullcrap[giant.gfycat.com] things.

On top of enemies being rather broken, this game uses frames as a timer for how things work. For example, more frames your weapon is in an enemy, the more durability damage it takes. Since DaS2 isn't moving faster in real time while at 60fps, your weapon takes twice as much durability damage potentially, when compared to 30fps. Also your rolls will have a tendancy to not work properly (Jumping can work pretty reliably though), and just simple button inputs can be buggy when at 60fps. Like.. I have a huge delay before I start sprinting, but locking to 30fps fixes that and it is really annoying.

Bad port issues aside; Is the game good on its own merits? Well... I had some fun, but spells don't feel particularly well balanced post mid-game, the +10 mundane dagger is rather overpowered for backstabs, and a lot of the gear people use seems to constantly be hit and miss.

Enviroments feel uninspired and very classic high-fantasy. They are not much different in idea in comparison to Demon and DaS1, but the issue is that the other two games were consistant with the paths. In Demon, you go to a storm temple, you finish at a storm temple (with a rather awesome air based boss). In DaS2, you start at a mountain side at night, end up at a mountain full of poison at day, then a windmill tower filled with poison, then you finish in a volcano. I suppose you can make the arguement that volcanos are toxic, but the lead-up to going into a volcano was non-existant and was really confusing.

Have I mentioned that the AI is dumb as rocks? I think I have but I will reitterate:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=262325070

Also areas have weird clipping:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=261770108

And seriously, this game has weird clipping:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=261770107

tl;dr : 6/10, better than Revelations 2012 but still makes me mad in a bad way.

Edit: This is a game you want to have a recording program ready for at all times. Because when it gets weird, it gets weird.

reviewText:
Yes, it's technically a superior PC port than the original; I don't remember a single instance of frame rate drop, lag or glitched graphics in my entire time playing it. Also the connection issues that the original game had are almost gone completely thanks to the transfer to Steam's servers. Unfortunately that's where the improvements seem to end.

Graphics:
Some of the later areas are really impressive, namely Drangleic Castle and the Shrine of Amana, however the majority of the game is aesthetically bland and uninspired and graphically poor, the use of repeating textures is prominent throughout a lot of the areas (Shaded Woods looks terrible no matter how close you are to the surface). I can only assume that the areas had to be redone when From Software realised that the hardware the game needed to run on would not be able to handle the graphics we saw in the E3 demo, and so the areas they had already completed had to have a shoddy re-texturing while the later areas were able to be given higher quality textures; I'm not sure if that is how it really went down in development but it's the only reason I can think of for the massive downgrade in comparison. Aesthetically most areas really lack that sense of mood and atmosphere that even the worst areas of Dark Souls 1 managed to pull off, with some areas being completely forgettable until you see it again in the bonfire warp menu.

Enemies:
Most of the enemies feel more frustrating to fight than a challenge to be overcome, as they can simply flail you with attacks with no downtime or even any kind of choreography of which attack they're about to do, as a result you just have to hit them in the hopes that you've chosen a moment when they don't decide to instantly perform a jab attack. Some fights become really frustrating as the game throws several enemies at you and unless you have some ranged attacks or a melee weapon with a sweeping attack you're likely to be overpowered as they ambush you from several directions. Again this is a downgrade from the Dark Souls 1 enemies which would be initially difficult but become easier as you got used to their attack patterns and became more skilled from playing. Also the enemy types are mostly uninspired save from a few interesting ideas that don't really work out, such as those turtle guys from the trailer, but mostly you'll be fighting generic solder guys.

Bosses:
At one point you're put against the Belfry Gargoyles from Dark Souls 1, only there's five of them instead of just two; while the boss was a complete copy-paste, right down to the music, I have to say that this was probably my favourite fight in the game which just goes to show how poor most of the bosses are, usually it's a case of hugging their leg while their attacks miss you. The only new boss I really enjoyed was the Ancient Dragon, which genuinely required skill and couldn't be spanked with two other sunbros like most of the bosses, though he still had to rely on a cheap fire breath attack that was difficult to flee from due to not quite knowing where the boss would attack from while airbourne. The only thing I would say I liked about the bosses was the designs for many of them were quite well done, namely Mytha, The Rotten, the giant bosses and the Demon of Song.

Music:
Not much to say on this point, the music was serviceable for the most part but mostly forgettable. Many of the tracks from Dark Souls 1 would get the blood pumping and had a memorable melody to them, whereas the music in Dark Souls 2 is more of a subtle background tune. To summarise, it's technically a good soundtrack, but I found it mostly forgettable.

Story:
Again the story takes a backseat and allows the player to discover it on their own terms if it interests them, which is what I liked about the first game. However while in Dark Souls 1 it felt like all the story elements were fleshed out yet subtle, I never really got that feeling with this game; in Dark Souls 1 everything had its place and allowed for speculation on how it all fit together and felt like it was an expertly crafted world, while Dark Souls 2, set in the same world, somehow feels more shallow and you can imagine that most of it was put together because it looks cool" or "the fans would like it". The NPC stories are also mostly non-existent
date: with the exception of Lucatiel's storyline and Pate and Creighton's converging storylines. Mostly the NPCs will come to Majula and sell their wares
recommended:
and that will be the end of their story.

Recommend?
Despite my mostly negative comments I'd still recommend this game on some level
hoursPlayed: I got 60 hours of gameplay out of it and I enjoyed a good number of those hours. If this was your first Souls game you might not feel as disappointed by the presentation
voteText: though I feel you'd still get frustrated by the cheap enemies and lack of real tactics in the boss fights. While I played the first game several times over
helpfulPercent: I can't see myself finishing this one a second time."

reviewText:
I had heard horror stories about the difficulty of the souls games so I d never picked one of these dark fantasy hack and slash before;

I am glad I finally did, t is an excellent game.

It is unforgiving but it has a great atmosphere and is clearly designed to reward exploration and persistence. The ramping up of difficulty of enemies means it is easier to play by venturing into the first part of areas, stopping when enemies level make it nightmarish, going into another area and coming back to progress in other areas after that. I am only 10 hours in but I am enjoying it a lot so far, and I am far from being good at it.

The unforgiving nature of the game means that minor occasional flaws like hits not registering can be a bit infuriating, especially when it leads to losing a bunch of souls. But overall it works very well. Beating a boss after having died to it several times to figure its full range of moves and how to approach the combat (and also, to manage to execute the proper series of actions and reactions during the whole combat) gives a great feeling of achievement.

Do not let the stories about the difficulty turn you away from this game. It is well worth a try if you like medieval action RPGs. It is tough but not impossible.

But what is a must buy for me, is the Old iron king dlc, 2-3 of the most diffcult and ♥♥♥♥ kicking bosses are in that 1 dlc, the whole dlc itself is pretty good aswell, really challenging on my first run.
The dlc's will give u that real challenge you'd expect for the Ds games , fume knight will kill u so many times you'll remember that guy for the next couple of months.

I give it a 8.5/10 cause of lag issue's, bad hitboxes on critical bosses and some bonfire points which spawn u near mob ganksquads all the time. All do-able but quite annoying.

+ The people complaining that From screwed them over, yes they did, till a certain point. U still get the new update and all it's new things, the fixed Ds2. Unless u really care much about the 6 man pvp (just a havel, hexer and pyromancy ganksquad cluster ♥♥♥♥, so i srsly couldn't care less) and the improved graphics aren't much of a big deal either.

reviewText:
It's very good, but not an improvement in every way over the original.

It's still a game about patience, exploration,  and murdering a bunch of stuff.  There's souls to collect, equipment to improve, and blood stains of fallen players everywhere. If you liked the first one, you'll almost certainly like this one.  If the idea of a challenging-but-fair game that isn't a hand-holding power fantasy appeals, you might like this. That said, allow me to blab a little bit about the changes I didn't like.

The biggest step backwards is the level design.  In Dark Souls 1, all the areas were connected and interwoven in interesting ways.  If you saw a bridge early in the game, you would probably get there later.  Dark Souls 2 doesn't do this very much.  The areas feel disconnected, and that makes it feel lazy.  It's like Demon Souls (or Super Mario!), where you've got the separate worlds that are all cool on their own but there's no real connection between them.   Dark Souls 1 made me expect more.

The other step backwards is the story.  I don't think I like it as much as the first one.  It starts off on a bad foot, with two cut scenes and entirely too much dialog and exposition.  My guess is they wanted to be absolutely certain that every new player really got it that their character was undead, and cursed, and undead, and also undead.  Maybe players in the previous game didn't listen to Oscar and got confused? No one's fault but their own, but I guess they wanted to cater to that crowd. But even after that, there are more NPCs and they tend to talk more. They also don't seem to have their own agendas in the same way the ones in Dark Souls 1 did.  Maybe that's fine, but it made it feel more like a traditional RPG where vendors sit around and wait for you to need them.

The bosses also aren't quite as memorable.  In the first one, the big four bosses you were told about in the intro cut scene.  There was a nice build up when you had a showdown with the badass from the opening cut scene. Not so much here.

But that negativity aside, it's still pretty solid.  You still get killed if you're sloppy or careless.  There are traps that will ruin your day if you're not paying attention.  If you like a challenging and rewarding game, it's worth playing.

reviewText: Gameplay - The gameplay takes all the great things from the original and makes them more refined and balanced, for the most part anyway. Rolling now actually requires skill rather than just rolling past everything, and it is assumed that you learn it to get far in the game at all, as the some of the most powerful attacks in the game can only be countered by doing so (Dark Magic, Great Hammers/Swords just to name a few). Where this game fails in some respects is the boss and enemy design. In the original there would be a few tough enemies in one area with heavy swings and low mobility, and the object of play was controlling their attacks and anticipating their next move, Dark Souls 2 seems to forget that this is where the combat system shines the brightest a lot of the time though, placing many enemies in one room just so they can stunlock you to death. And Bosses like the Royal Rat Vanguard and Belfry Gargoyles are just great bosses from the last game with a tonne more enemies shoved in for more artificial difficulty. This is my main gripe with the game, most of it isn't skill, it is just waiting until a set of enemies have completed their attack animations and taking a few safe hits in the downtime between the next (An example of this would be the set of three knight enemies in Heides Tower of Flame). This doesn't play to the strengths of the combat system and makes the game less fun overall. Speaking of boss designs, most bosses are predictable, humanoid Strafe/Roll fests with little to no substance, the ones that aren't are usually filled to the brim with enemies. Usually. There is one boss encounter that is true genius, and he is optional and out of the way for no particular reason, Darklurker. This boss is brilliant, seemingly easy at first, he has slow, easily dodgable attacks with long windups, but then, he suddenly splits into two. And usually this would be a problem like a said before, having you wait out his attacks and such but not this time around, it turns into a beautiful almost dance-like pattern that takes much more skill than most bosses to complete. This is how the whole game should have been structured, but it seems to have fallen off mark. That said, it was still thoroughly enjoyable and i would recommend an all-bosses run to anyone with the time, you get this game for the gameplay. Thank god it is good. Score: A-\n\nStory - The story is an abstract piece to many people. Instead of the game just outright telling you the legends of people and places, you are meant to piece together it's tale using a plethora of techniques, in-game descriptions for items, talking to people and the environment being just a few of the ways you can go about it. The game begins with a short cutscene of your player being told that you are cursed, that your timelines and sense of self will have no meaning, that you will become a wretched hollow come time past, and that you will stand before it's decrepit gate without really knowing why". These things are left as speculation for the player for the most part. And are never answered directly

recommended: but the legends and stories of people scattered across the land are really where the brilliance is at. Score: B\n\nControls - Ahh controls. The first game was a horrible port to PC

reviewText:
The opening words
Dark Souls was a terrible port. We all remember how terrible the graphics were, how optimization was borked and framerate suffered, and how butchered the controls for the keyboard/mouse were. We all loved the game for gameplay, but we all hated the game for the PC port. From Software promised that this would not be the case with Dark Souls II. That the platform will be treated with the respect it deserves. Did they manage it?
As with every Souls game, Dark Souls II is an action/adventure game, similar in a way to the Zelda series. You travel the more or less open world, fight off enemies, deal with some simple puzzles, beat bosses, and aquire new cool abilities for your character. What's possibly the most iconic thing about a Souls game is the fact that it's HARD. You will die a lot in this game, but usually if you are calm you can avoid dying in the same place multiple times, and if you do fall you are sent back to the last bonfire. There are quite many of those and I never felt like the game punished me too much in this regard. The thing is if you die, you lose all unspent souls, which are currency in this game. You use souls to level up your character and to buy weapons/spells/armor. After dying you can still get your souls back, if you get to the same spot without dying again. So this game basically punishes you for screwing up on the same part multiple times, which is fine by me, but it takes some getting used to.
I won't say much about the story, because for a non-fan it would be too complicated to understand, and fans already know it. What I will say is this: you play as an undead. You once had a wife, a child, a purpose... but the undead curse took that from you. And as every undead, you slowly start to forget your past. Now the only thing that drives you is the lust for souls, and the possibility of learning more about the undead curse. But will you manage to succeed before you lose your mind and become hollow? Will you find a cure for your condition, or are you destined to die and be reborn over, and over again?

The good
If you own a gamepad and you loved the first Dark Souls, stop reading this and go buy DS II. That's it. The gameplay, although little different, still delivers the same Souls experience we've come to expect from a Souls game. The action is satisfying, the environments great by design, and the stories interesting, if you are willing to dive in. The graphics on PC are better than on the consoles, so at least the devs were truthful to their word, but more on that later. The game should run correctly on a PC that meets the requirements.
The combat, which is the most important part of the game takes some getting used to at first. But once you get the controls down, you will enjoy this part the most. The enemies can behave unpredictably, and the game will be a challange even for the fans of the first Dark Souls. There are a lot of items, weapons and armor that you can get from enemies/buy from merchants. Every piece of equipment has it's own model, so for all of you looks-first kind of players this is a treat.
There are some gameplay changes (since the original Dark Souls) that I liked, particularly the splitting of Endurance into 2 stats. Now you have a stat that increases your stamina, another that lets you wear heavier stuff, and one more that offers you higher speed of moves like dodges or drinking health potions. This let's you tweak your character more, which is good. Oh, and the online features are FUN as hell. That's good too.

The bad
I know what you want to know: can I play with mouse and keyboard? Answer: Yes. Sort of. Kinda... maybe. It is possible, and I tried it for myself, but you will have so much easier time just by picking up a 360 gamepad. The fact that the game shows you only controller button prompts doesn't help eighter. If you are set on playing with keys I'd suggest tweaking the controls first, and then during the gameplay, to find what is the most comfortable for you.
Graphics could look better. We've seen the beta/demo builds and the lighting looked awesome, so why is it, that the finished game looks nothing like this? There's barely any use for a torch, aside from few areas in the game and even there you can still see more clearly than you should be without the light. That also would have been a great gameplay change: will you sacrifice a weapon, or a shield and carry a torch in one hand? Or will you sacrifice visibility for better offence/defence? Nope. Scrapped, probably because consoles couldn't handle it. Tsk, tsk. Don't do that again, From Software. I'm watching you. If you pull a switch like that again, I'll stop buying your stuff. This time I'll overlook it, even though it's bad...

The ugly
There are two things I really hate about this game. First is a change from the original. In Dark Souls 1 it didn't really matter if you lost all your souls. You could always farm some more, because monster would respawn every time you rested at the bonfire. Not the case anymore. Monsters respawn only 14 times, or so I'm told (haven't really counted myself). If you kill a monster 15th time, it stops spawning and you can't farm it anymore. This has some good effects: you can clear the way to a boss, and just focus on trying to beat him, rather than dealing with the hardships on the way. But to me this seeems like a mechanic to punish players who struggle with the difficulty. A good player won't need to farm souls, so he won't care about kill limits. But a bad player may want to level up and level the playing field a little before going to the boss battle. This is quite frankly unnecessary. There is a way of respawning the monsters in an area but that involves increasing the difficulty, which is the last thing you want if you are already struggling. Mind you, you can still obtain more souls by going online and helping other players with bosses - you use an item called White Sign Soapstone, which you get quite early, and then other players can summon you in that spot in their own world. You are then tasked with helping that player and protecting him from dangers. Reward? A share in souls he gets and an item if you manage to help him beat a boss. You could also leave one area and go farm another, but again, it will deplete as well at some point and I don't like that.
The second ugly thing is major. The servers for the game are ♥♥♥♥ED. I've had the game for little over a week and I've been unable to connect multiple times. And even if I did connect and got pulled into the game by other players, the lag was sometimes just impossible. I think the devs said that the online games will take place on a server, but that's clearly not the case. The lag depends solely on your connection, and the host's connection. If his provider suck, then you'll lag a lot, which is annoying for any kind of PvP. You can still play offline, but the game is just much less fun.
Also I've found some graphical glitches. For example, after beating two dragon riders in the castle and resting at the next bofire, turn back and look at the floor near the walls. Doesn't really influence the gameplay, but is still ugly.

The lowdown
Overall, I'd say the game is worth buying. The gameplay itself is fantastic, and that's what matters the most in the end, right? And if the server problems are dealt with, the game will be near perfect. Well if not for the controls that are still bad on keyboar/mouse. So all in all I'd say you will HATE this game at first. But if you make yourself go through the first rage, and get little good at it and start succeeding you will LOVE every single minute of it. Try it out for yourself and see if you have what it takes.

reviewText:
Yes, it's technically a superior PC port than the original; I don't remember a single instance of frame rate drop, lag or glitched graphics in my entire time playing it. Also the connection issues that the original game had are almost gone completely thanks to the transfer to Steam's servers. Unfortunately that's where the improvements seem to end.

Graphics:
Some of the later areas are really impressive, namely Drangleic Castle and the Shrine of Amana, however the majority of the game is aesthetically bland and uninspired and graphically poor, the use of repeating textures is prominent throughout a lot of the areas (Shaded Woods looks terrible no matter how close you are to the surface). I can only assume that the areas had to be redone when From Software realised that the hardware the game needed to run on would not be able to handle the graphics we saw in the E3 demo, and so the areas they had already completed had to have a shoddy re-texturing while the later areas were able to be given higher quality textures; I'm not sure if that is how it really went down in development but it's the only reason I can think of for the massive downgrade in comparison. Aesthetically most areas really lack that sense of mood and atmosphere that even the worst areas of Dark Souls 1 managed to pull off, with some areas being completely forgettable until you see it again in the bonfire warp menu.

Enemies:
Most of the enemies feel more frustrating to fight than a challenge to be overcome, as they can simply flail you with attacks with no downtime or even any kind of choreography of which attack they're about to do, as a result you just have to hit them in the hopes that you've chosen a moment when they don't decide to instantly perform a jab attack. Some fights become really frustrating as the game throws several enemies at you and unless you have some ranged attacks or a melee weapon with a sweeping attack you're likely to be overpowered as they ambush you from several directions. Again this is a downgrade from the Dark Souls 1 enemies which would be initially difficult but become easier as you got used to their attack patterns and became more skilled from playing. Also the enemy types are mostly uninspired save from a few interesting ideas that don't really work out, such as those turtle guys from the trailer, but mostly you'll be fighting generic solder guys.

Bosses:
At one point you're put against the Belfry Gargoyles from Dark Souls 1, only there's five of them instead of just two; while the boss was a complete copy-paste, right down to the music, I have to say that this was probably my favourite fight in the game which just goes to show how poor most of the bosses are, usually it's a case of hugging their leg while their attacks miss you. The only new boss I really enjoyed was the Ancient Dragon, which genuinely required skill and couldn't be spanked with two other sunbros like most of the bosses, though he still had to rely on a cheap fire breath attack that was difficult to flee from due to not quite knowing where the boss would attack from while airbourne. The only thing I would say I liked about the bosses was the designs for many of them were quite well done, namely Mytha, The Rotten, the giant bosses and the Demon of Song.

Music:
Not much to say on this point, the music was serviceable for the most part but mostly forgettable. Many of the tracks from Dark Souls 1 would get the blood pumping and had a memorable melody to them, whereas the music in Dark Souls 2 is more of a subtle background tune. To summarise, it's technically a good soundtrack, but I found it mostly forgettable.

Story:
Again the story takes a backseat and allows the player to discover it on their own terms if it interests them, which is what I liked about the first game. However while in Dark Souls 1 it felt like all the story elements were fleshed out yet subtle, I never really got that feeling with this game; in Dark Souls 1 everything had its place and allowed for speculation on how it all fit together and felt like it was an expertly crafted world, while Dark Souls 2, set in the same world, somehow feels more shallow and you can imagine that most of it was put together because it looks cool" or "the fans would like it". The NPC stories are also mostly non-existent
date: with the exception of Lucatiel's storyline and Pate and Creighton's converging storylines. Mostly the NPCs will come to Majula and sell their wares
recommended:
and that will be the end of their story.

Recommend?
Despite my mostly negative comments I'd still recommend this game on some level
hoursPlayed: I got 60 hours of gameplay out of it and I enjoyed a good number of those hours. If this was your first Souls game you might not feel as disappointed by the presentation
voteText: though I feel you'd still get frustrated by the cheap enemies and lack of real tactics in the boss fights. While I played the first game several times over

reviewText:
The souls series is one of my most favorite game series i ever had the chance to experiance, but this is a review so i will not praise it like if it was a masterpiece!

I will bring upp som points and tell you what i think about them.

Gameplay

It does what it should alright, it's difficult to master the controls at times but you will have it hammerd in some how. Even do i have put in 300+ hours in Dark souls 1 i still just have failed so many times at some bosses and other places. I think the bosses are as hard as they should be but i'm not a fan off the new hit tracking added to many large and powerfull bosses. The hitbox is very precis and suprises me at sometimes, but as i said before the new hit tracking is not a great point. I hope that FromSoftware will re think this in the future.

Environment and secrets

This games has many secrets hidden in the enviroment, that makes it very intresting to go around and look for more then just a ordinary way. like the other souls games this game tries to stay quiet about all the diffrent items but fails att it's path design. It seems like they wanted to make strict paths with some small suprises that would trigger you to think it was creative about it. The environment is not as good as dark souls 1 beacuse it dosen't have as connected levels as in the rest off the games.  I think you too would agree at that. so Dark souls 2 has an enviroment that under achieve in level design and does however a better job off keeping it's secrets.

Story and reference

I'ts story stays with the theme off not telling you anything. frankly i think that it's a bit sad that i don't feel a need to care about it either. As for references it has plenty off conections to dark souls 1, this might show that it has a hard time off trying to be it's own thing. i do agree it's nice to see some things are still around as for some besic weapons. some descreptions shows that this new land was once (spoiler ahead) lordran but as off yet i would not say it's canon. it's story is as always in any case a mystery so don't expect any thing there.

Hardcoreness

As for some people it's very hard to get a grasp around this games way off thinking. i have played dark souls 1 for 300 hours+ so i had no problem with the game. i diden't enjoy some off the many ledges that made me fall to my death but i guess thats how hardcore the game got for me. i'd say it keeps you on your toes att plenty off times, but it's realy up to you.

Online Activity

Well i have had a both bad and a good time with pvp and co-op, But i think i will take my thoughts to a list for both pvp and co-op.

PvP
. Sometimes you have to see where your build fails and accept that to try and beat people in dark souls much uniqe way off putting you aginst random fighters.
. It's good that you can punish invaders in plenty of ways.
. Ganks can be a boring trip if you don't know what you are doing.
. All covenants that i have found have pvp in mind.

Co-op
. Hard to summon friends if you do not have a special ring.
. Randoms can be more enemy then ally sometimes.
. Some places you'll need Co-op.
. And other places you DON'T want co-op.

Final thoughts

Like freedom off building a somewhat uniqe hero with good options?
Like being tormented for not learning the controls?
Don't care much for a more connected enviroment?
Love to bash other players with everything from a simple sword to a massive burning steel hammer?

well if that's the case i'll think you'll like. But be warned if your a souls fan you might not like some things in this game.

reviewText:
This game can be put in the Action-RPG genre.
But a category has its limits. So let's describe it a bit more precisely.

Dark Souls 2 puts you in the role of a lone adventurer thrown in a dark-fantasy world where dealing with pitfalls and enemies demand skill and reasoning. Combat is both stats-based and skill-based. Stats are leveled up with the same curency that weapons are bought and repaired with : souls dropped from monsters.

The skill needed in combat and in navigating the terrain is one reason the game is regarded as a difficult one. The other is the punishing loss of all souls after an unsuccessful retrieval attempt.

While enemies are usually tough and the world is at times tricky to navigate, the game does a good job of connecting you with hints and warnings of dangerous zones left by players who experience the same challenges in their parallel world. One can also stumble upon signs offering help for tough fights when certain conditions are met. The player who offered his help is then loaded into the host's world and can assist in the difficult boss fight.

The game world is beautifully designed. Enemies and friendly characters are numerous and varied. They are believeable. The challenges are great. This is clearly an atmospheric game.

There is also different player-vs-player features in the game. Fun challenges as they may be, these challenges can be alleviated with in-game choices.

reviewText: Dark, dreary, and brutally unforgiving, this RPG is one of the few in recent memory that is truly difficult no matter how you play it.  Dark Souls 2 has next to no tutuorial and no guidance as to where you should go and in what order.  If you have someone holding your hand through it, or an online guide to follow, it may not be incredibly frustrating.\n\nThis game is the first RPG in recent memory that actually gives you the option to play it offline.  This has its own caveats however, and in a moment I will explain why.  First you must know that when you die, you drop all of your currently accrued  souls" (currency for everything in-game from repairing to leveling) and must run back to where you died in order to get them back.  If you can't make it that far
date: and die again - you have lost all of those original souls.  On top of that
hoursPlayed: and have reduced life in increasing increments each time you die.\n\nThe positive aspect for being online is that you can get an item that allows you to write a symbol on the floor
voteText: which allows players in that area to summon you to them as a "phantom" and to fight with them.  In this state
helpfulPercent: you cannot loot items from chests and you cannot interact with levers or doorways
votesHelpful: but as you help the other player you begin to gain back your humanity.  Once you fulfill your duty
votesTotal: you are teleported back to your own world
votesFunny: a human again - your hollowed state cured.\n\nThe negative aspect for being online (at least
commentsCount: it's a negative in my eyes) is that you can at almost any point be invaded by another player of your relative level for the soul purpose of surprise PvP.  Often times
column16: these players know what they are doing and
column17: for the PvP-inexperienced or super-casuals such as myself
column18: only serve as an annoying and stressful death.  This is why I opt to play in offline mode much of the time.\n\nStill
column19: Dark Souls 2 is an engaging and clearly challenging game.  One I would prefer to play with friends
column20: but still play on my own (very
column21: very slowly).  If you enjoy a true challenge and don't mind a steep learning curve
column22: this is a game you should consider."

reviewText:
NOTE: There's a re-release of this game coming up within a few months. Wait if you can.

Once in a while one can come across a game that is so immersive, deep, and vast that it raises the bar for great games. In this regard, Dark Souls 2 (and indeed the original Dark Souls) is in a league of its own. With its incredibly challenging and unforgiving gameplay, subtle storytelling, and fascinating environments, Dark Souls 2 is one of the best (if not THE best) games I've ever played, despite its flaws. If you haven't already, I could recommend starting with Dark Souls 1, but that is not at all necessary to enjoy DS2 to its fullest.

What's good about it:
- The gameplay. There's no hand-holding to be had here. You're thrown into a brutal world where even the lowliest of enemies can send you back to pre-school if you don't pay attention. The game is always challening, but hardly ever unfair. You lose, cry, swear, and probably rip your hair out because you're just not good enough yet. When you fail, you get back up and try again and again until you win, and when you do, you'll feel like the Best Player of Video Games Ever ™.
- The combat. The combat mechanics make for some of the most incredibly exhilarating battles I've ever fought in a game. The wide variety of weapons and their respective play styles has something to offer for everyone. Remember that Fashion Souls is the best Souls.
- The narrative. Or rather, the lack thereof. Nobody tells you where to go or what to do, and the actual story isn't delivered like we're used to. Instead, the world around you and the items you find will tell you the story. With a keen eye for details you'll be able to figure out the purpose of certain locations, characters, and items.
- The abstract approach to multiplayer. The concept of Phantoms being summoned to your world seamlessly as you explore the world is incredibly clever. You can at any time (outside of some safe zones) be invaded by another player in the form of a Dark Spirit, or summon another player to help you as a Phantom or Shade. There are other ways to be summoned/summon as well, which will at times leave you wondering if you just fought a player or an NPC.
- Copious amounts of sun-praising.

What's questionable:
- The PVP matchmaking. You can only be matched with people in your own tier, decided by the total amount of souls your character has acquired, whereas in Dark Souls 1 character were matched by their level. The system in DS2 seems like a step backwards. However, this will reportedly be fixed in the upcoming SotFS update.
- The addition of Agility. DS2 introduced a new stat, Agility, that determines the amount of invicibility frames your character gets when rolling and dodging, and the speed at which you can raise your shield. To get to the same amount of invicibility frames as in DS1, you have to dump a few levels into Adaptability, or the doding will feel very off if you're used to DS1. I can imagine that this was introduced to give agile characters an advantage, but it feels like a strange stat dump.
- The mouse + keyboard controls are simply inferior to playing with a controller. That said, they're a lot better than they were in DS1.

Dark Souls 2 in my opinion even better than Dark Souls 1, which is saying quite a lot, considering that Dark Souls is (was) my favourite game ever. Truly a worthy sequel. Do yourself a favour, play this game, and git gud.

reviewText:
Having never played this game's predecessors:  Dark souls prepare to die edition & Demon's Souls, i found this game odd and even buggy at first. But i hadn't really understood the concept of being hollow and very weak and the enormity of the leveling up in this game and of how difficult levels can be at times.

I was immediatly hooked on this game. The variety of items such as armors and weapons is excellent. I really like that it seems really simple to finish the entire game without realising that you haven't even gotten close to getting everything in the game and that to do so, you'll need persistent dedication.

This game really doesn't explain anything, not much of story  either. It defintatly makes up for it with amazing gameplay. Lots of Giant Bosses. The summoning system is a bit quirky. Sometimes, certain bosses are so difficult until you reach a certain level that the only way to beat them is by sommoning other players, but then no summoning signs will be visible and no other players available to summon. This is fixed later in the game with adding other NPC characters that you can summon to assist you.

Overall very good game. So many easter eggs are cramed into this game that really hadn't been apparent the first playthrough. Really don't like getting invaded by dark spirits ..kind of annoying if you're just trying to play single player.

Recommend to any Action-RGP fans

reviewText:
This game is fun and entertaining, but it requires a good deal of patience and tenacity to get through. Don't expect to do well at all on your first try, just concentrate on achieving one goal and move on from there. The story is similar to DSI In the fact that it's given to you piece meal from item descriptions and the snippets of information you can gather just from looking at your surroundings. The game itself is beautiful and pretty well balanced. The only real flaw that I can garner comes from the multiplayer aspect: Getting invaded randomly by a red completely breaks the immersion. Especially if their name is something along the lines of 420yoloxXexecutionerXxyolo420 and they're wearing havels and the jester chest.

Along similar lines the multiplayer EVERYWHERE THAT ISN'T JAPAN. Suffers from /ridiculous/ lag. You will get backstabbed from across a room. You will get hit by daggers from across a room. You will be hit with projectiles that haven't yet been fired. And the worst part is: there is no disadvantage to being the cause of lag. In fact, some players choose to have their computer overworked to create lag as that lowers the frame rate. And since this is DS lower frame rate = more invincibility frames and less equipment degredation. As a result PvP is an on again off again sort of deal. Its great when it works and its ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed awful when it doesn't.

Don't even get me started on the pvp builds people use. There is nothing more frustrating than a havel clown with great magic barrier spamming laggy resonant souls at you.

7/10
From,
You need to have more than two servers for the entirety of your community, and one of them should not be Japan only. Honestly...

reviewText: My pick for GOTY 2014. This is the first game I ever pre-ordered and I was not dissapointed in any way. The look and feel of the game is nothing short of amazing, combat is tight and responsive and the challenge is, like in the first DS, high as ever, as it should be. Online play works great most of the time (much better than the first DS, at least for me) and the community is massive. One warning, though; this game is not for those who quit easily or just don't feel like putting any effort to master the game - you will die a lot of times during your playthrough but that's just a part of the game. Replay value is extremely high because of the abundance of secrets and very competitive (or jolly co-operative) online play. Buy it and play it - you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Much has been said about the difficulty of the Dark Souls series. For many it's the main draw of the franchise, and those people might be disappointed that Dark Souls 2 is the easiest of the three. That is not to say that the game is in any way easy, though. It is, however, much more accessible for newcomers, and that makes it the best Souls game yet.

For those who can look past the game's clunky user interface and the less-than-ideal control scheme for mouse and keyboard, a brilliant action RPG of unparalleled depth and complexity awaits. From Software once again manages to deliver a beautiful and mysterious world to explore, filled with interesting and complex characters to meet and befriend.. or behead.

To me, Dark Souls 2 is the finest entry in a franchise that has already rewritten video game history, and this latest entry in the franchise is worthy of its legacy. It will break you, and you will love it. It will teach you, and you will learn. This is the Dark Souls way.

Bearer of the curse.. the kingdom of Drangleic beckons for its next monarch.

reviewText:
Firstly, a much much better port than the original Dark souls on PC, effort was clearly made here and that's good to see, running at a very smooth 60fps almost constantly and having a good amount of video settings but it shouldn't be hard to run on maximum with a decent computer.

While also having improved keyboard+mouse controls (with a bit of rebinding in the menus) it can be played if not with a little added difficulty in my experience, and so I would still suggest using a controller for this.

The game itself is beautiful having some very pretty landscapes and areas, though something feels a little lacking at times in the design and some enemies and bosses can come off as a bit bland and forgettable but some bosses stick out as rather well made, to summarise some enemy and area design feels as if it could have been better while others are very well made to the point of taking a moment to just look around, unless it's a boss and you get your face caved in for admiring it.

While the series is renowned for it's difficulty any souls veteran won't have a hard time here, some changes were made like more items to restore health but you will lose out on max hp for consecutive deaths without restoring your humanity though as someone who has finished both Dark 1 and Demon's souls I more often than not had at least a dozen humanity on me so if you're pretty good this shouldn't be a concern but can be off putting to those less confident in their ability.

Summoning for co-op feels much easier this time around especially if you grab a certain ring that restricts multiplayer based on a chosen deity to play with your friends, it feels much more responsive and you should see less lag spikes and experience less lag-stabs in pvp, though with the mention of pvp it is possible to finish the game being human a majority of the time and almost never be invaded aside from certain pvp areas which you may pass through which seem like super hot spots this time around.

Overall I think this is a fantastic port and that From Software clearly made an effort this time around to do justice to the platform and would recommend this to any fan of the Souls series though for a starting point if you haven't played a Souls game before I'd sooner recommend the first if purely for the lack of a penalty for death as you learn the mechanics though if you get it on pc, be prepared to look up a couple of mods namely DSfix + DSCfix.

TL;DR:
Great port
Better functioning multiplayer
Similar difficulty to previous entries (personal experience may differ)
Somewhat lacking enemy & area design at times

reviewText:
9/10. My only complaints go to the lore which feels slightly lacking, in comparasion to the original installment, as well as the fact that some covenants require ridiculous amounts of play to achieve the highest rank in (looking at you, BoB and BS). Also, the PvP is slightly unbalanced in some departments, but that will be patched very shortly.

All in all, a really fantastic action-RPG. The difficulty is what makes the Souls games what they are, and DS2 delivers. While the difficulty at times might be a bit unfair, such as an enemy jumping down from a space you can't see originally, but most of the times it holds up to its predecessor. The difficulty is easily dispatched if you tread lightly and mind your surroundings. If a boss or an enemy has an attack which can kill you in one or two hits, it is a slow attack that can be avoided if you think quickly. If you mindlessly charge in you will rest-assuredly die a very painful death.

The music and atmosphere is great. Most of the times, only bosses actually have music, and that is great. You know ♥♥♥♥'s about to go down. Besides, since the areas themselves do not have music, it becomes so much more atmospheric. You are constantly on your toes and any noise is more easily registered due to the lack of music.

The character progression system (leveling up) is fantastic. You start as a stereotypical class - warrior, sorcerer, bandit etc, but after that, you can go whatever path you feel like. Spell-slinging, fragile caster with a massive two-handed sword? No problem! Backstabbing, stealthy dual-wielding assassin with full noisy plate mail? Sure, why not?

Another strong point this game has which the original Dark Souls lacked is that this one has a much more open world. You can travel to two different areas right off the bat, and after a few minutes of saving souls, you can go to a third area. About 1/5 into the game, you can go to a fourth place. The end-game is rather linear, however, but that's only about 20% of the game. Besides, it would not really make sense to have the final areas be too open-ended, in my opinion.

Player interaction is much more polished here. Compared to DS1, I very rarely encounter heavy laggers. There are covenants for all sort of player interaction - helping other players repel invaders, co-oping, invading other players, getting summoned to duel with a player 1v1, fight in arenas, etc etc. Some weapons are slightly on the strong side in PvP, but as I earlier stated, that is getting fixed in just a few days from when I am writing this.

All in all, great game, great community.

9/10, ♥♥♥♥ing buy it lol

reviewText:
This right here is the pinnacle of RPG games. From the brilliant, beautiful and immersive  world, to the meaty, fun and intense combat, with a unique story that is not forced on the player, and an amazing integration of multiplayer into a sinlgeplayer experience while making it lore friendly, those are the things that make Dark Souls 2 one of the best JRPG's out there. its challenging in every aspect, it has an amazing soundtrack, EPIC and memorable boss fights, variety in enemies, and a great sense of achievement with every step you take that no other game offers.

This is an absolute classic that wont be forgotten for a long time. RECOMMENDED to all RPG fans, but be warned... its as brutal as its predecessors and there wont be any hand holding.

Also i found mouse and keyboard controls to be very awkward, therefor i recommend a joystick for a better experience.

reviewText:
Praise the Sun!

Dark Souls II, though it may be an easier game (by far) than its predecessors, is all I could have hoped it to be. It's a fun, (if a bit grind-y) challenging hack n' slash, with plenty of backstory and secrets to keep you playing and interested. The first run through may feel a bit too casual for veterans of the series, but NG+ is where the real Dark Souls experience begins.

If you have the patience to run through the game the first time, hopefully the successive playthroughs will be what have you coming back for more.
