reviewText:
Returning for the third iteration of the series, and the successor to my personal favorite game of all time, Dark Souls, is the epic  new adventure, Dark Souls II. I've played for about 20 hours so far and I must say, fromSoft has delivered yet another masterpiece in their notoriously difficult Action RPG saga.

I've been a souls player from the very beginning of the series, which started with Demon's Souls on the PS3. I was instantly addicted to the polished, action oriented gameplay and the plethora of great fantasy lore. The story of the souls series has improved substantially with each new title, and Dark Souls II is by far the most comprehensive in the series to date.

The environments, as usual, provide plenty of spectacular things to see and inspect. Even the still backgrounds include a ridiculous amount of detail, which adds to the overall sensation that you are indeed a part of this twisted, dark world. I will say that  the environments don't mesh quite as seemlessly as the original Dark Souls did, but this is a very minor complaint considering the fidelity and detail that each section of the new game provides. No two places look the same for the most part, which certainly adds a new layer of excitement every time you move on to a new area.

The difficulty, which the souls series is probably most notorious for, returns with a vengeance in Dark Souls II. In some ways the game is much harder than either of the two previous games, but there is certainly some give and take in that regard(i've always stood by my statement that the game is hard, but NEVER unfair. Learn from your mistakes, and Souls will reward you in kind). You are punished more than ever for dying which is something that will inevitably happen a 100 times + per playthrough, but there has been some balancing features added as well to somewhat counteract this new gameplay element. The world is less crytpic and vague than previous iterations of the series, meaning players are more informed on what needs to be accomplished for them to achieve their ultimate goal of defeating all the bosses and moving on. This was a potentially vaunting addition for many souls players, but in my opinion, it made the world come alive more than it ever has in previous titles. Descriptions of items(for the most part) are more detailed, NPC characters are more helpful, and the beloved messaging system for online play has been improved dramatically. This is just one of the many new changes Dark Souls II implements, and segues nicely into my next topic; Dark Souls II and the new multiplayer format.

In previous games, the multiplayer system was far less fleshed out than it is in Dark Souls II. You couldn't directly play with your friends in the original Dark Souls due to the splitting of servers(ironically this wasn't the case in the original game, Demon's Souls), and some covenants you could join had very little to offer the player in terms of reward and dedication. This has(for the most part) changed in Dark Souls II. The summoning system in Dark Souls II has changed dramatically, but the most important feature in my humble opinion is the ability to play with your friends online. The Souls games at heart have always been a single player game first and foremost, with the online system and it's benefits being secondary" to the player's individual experience. While this is still the case
date: the benefits of playing online have increased a tremendous amount. You can once again summon your friends
recommended: rating messages has become infinitely easier and the connection issues and long load times when summoning a player to "your" world have decreased dramatically. Many people who played the Souls game's in the past can attest to the multitude of connection issues that occured when trying to summon another player to help you fight a boss or clear an area. Many times
hoursPlayed: one would sit and wait for almost 2 full minutes before the annoying "summoning failed" banner flashed across the screen. In Dark Souls II
voteText: no longer do you have to wait to find out if someone is being summoned to your world. You are notified immediately if someone cannot be summoned
helpfulPercent: allowing you to move on and attempt to summon somebody else instead of waiting for several minutes
votesHelpful: only to find out that the player you tried to summon isn't coming to your aid. Rating messages has also become infinitely easier
votesTotal: no longer requiring the player to use their orange soapstone sign to rate a message left by another player. You can simply select "rate message" from the message read screen
votesFunny: and this is a marked improvement over the previous titles. Messages are an important feature in Souls games
commentsCount: allowing you to leave a note on the ground for other players to read. Messages pertain to things such as traps
column16: tough enemies
column17: or hidden treasures throughout the world. Messages can also be used as a "griefing" tool for the more sinister players
column18: leaving fake advice in the form of a message to confuse or kill other players playing in that area. However you decide to use messages though
column19: the system has been improved by an incredible margin.\n\nCovenants also make a return in Dark Souls II
column20: which are esentially game altering "clubs" that you can join throughout your adventure to alter how the world responds to you. PVP has always been a popular feature in the Souls series
column21: and the covenants in Dark Souls II add to the format first introduced in Dark Souls by a great deal. Covenants aren't exclusive to PVP alone however; many convenants are available to assist in CO-OP as well as PVE. Unlike the previous game
column22: however
column23: the rewards for "ranking up" in Dark Souls II are far more beneficial than before. Aside from the obvious gameplay changes a convenant provides
column24: they also give the player rewards for their dedication to the current covenant they belong to.\n\nThe only complaint I have with the game so far is how you spend your souls to "level". In the previous game
column25: you could collect your souls from killing monsters and level up at any bonfire in the game. This idea has been scratched in Dark Souls II for a more conventional "home base"
column26: meaning the player must travel back to the home area if they wish to spend their souls. Also
column27: many features of the game that involve bonfire's require the user to go back to the hub world and use that specific bonfire. This was the one "step back" so to speak that fromSoft did
column28: but since I play on PC
column29: load times are hardly an issue(there was far more complaining about this for console players since the load times were significantly longer). While a minor inconvenience to say the least
column30: it certainly doesn't ruin the game by any stretch of the imagination.\n\nIn short
column31: Dark Souls II delivers another epic experience
column32: from monsterous boss battles to intense PVP fights with players around the globe. fromSoft didn't try to reinvent the wheel here
column33: but instead added and improved on an already fantastic gaming platform. If you haven't played a Souls game yet
column34: this would be a fantastic place to start. While Dark Souls and Dark Souls II take place in the same relative "universe"
column35: they are indeed stand-alone titles that require no previous knowledge of either Dark Souls or Demon's Souls to understand. If you haven't played either of those games
column37: you are missing out on two of the best games ever made. Dark Souls II improves on everything that Dark Souls couldn't(or didn't) achieve
column38: and does it with the same flash and excitement of the previous games. Despite the one flaw I mentioned
column39: this game will more than likely go down as one of my favorites ever
column40: and will demand my attention for years to come(Or until the next Souls game!!). Be prepared to die
column41: but also know that every time you do perish
column42: it won't be for naught. This is a game about memory as much as it is about skill
column43: and for those who wish to put forth the effort
column44: they will be greatly rewareded with one of the most polished and exciting games ever made."

reviewText: One of the best games out there! But to learn the game you have to be patient.

reviewText:
The souls series is one of my most favorite game series i ever had the chance to experiance, but this is a review so i will not praise it like if it was a masterpiece!

I will bring upp som points and tell you what i think about them.

Gameplay

It does what it should alright, it's difficult to master the controls at times but you will have it hammerd in some how. Even do i have put in 300+ hours in Dark souls 1 i still just have failed so many times at some bosses and other places. I think the bosses are as hard as they should be but i'm not a fan off the new hit tracking added to many large and powerfull bosses. The hitbox is very precis and suprises me at sometimes, but as i said before the new hit tracking is not a great point. I hope that FromSoftware will re think this in the future.

Environment and secrets

This games has many secrets hidden in the enviroment, that makes it very intresting to go around and look for more then just a ordinary way. like the other souls games this game tries to stay quiet about all the diffrent items but fails att it's path design. It seems like they wanted to make strict paths with some small suprises that would trigger you to think it was creative about it. The environment is not as good as dark souls 1 beacuse it dosen't have as connected levels as in the rest off the games.  I think you too would agree at that. so Dark souls 2 has an enviroment that under achieve in level design and does however a better job off keeping it's secrets.

Story and reference

I'ts story stays with the theme off not telling you anything. frankly i think that it's a bit sad that i don't feel a need to care about it either. As for references it has plenty off conections to dark souls 1, this might show that it has a hard time off trying to be it's own thing. i do agree it's nice to see some things are still around as for some besic weapons. some descreptions shows that this new land was once (spoiler ahead) lordran but as off yet i would not say it's canon. it's story is as always in any case a mystery so don't expect any thing there.

Hardcoreness

As for some people it's very hard to get a grasp around this games way off thinking. i have played dark souls 1 for 300 hours+ so i had no problem with the game. i diden't enjoy some off the many ledges that made me fall to my death but i guess thats how hardcore the game got for me. i'd say it keeps you on your toes att plenty off times, but it's realy up to you.

Online Activity

Well i have had a both bad and a good time with pvp and co-op, But i think i will take my thoughts to a list for both pvp and co-op.

PvP
. Sometimes you have to see where your build fails and accept that to try and beat people in dark souls much uniqe way off putting you aginst random fighters.
. It's good that you can punish invaders in plenty of ways.
. Ganks can be a boring trip if you don't know what you are doing.
. All covenants that i have found have pvp in mind.

Co-op
. Hard to summon friends if you do not have a special ring.
. Randoms can be more enemy then ally sometimes.
. Some places you'll need Co-op.
. And other places you DON'T want co-op.

Final thoughts

Like freedom off building a somewhat uniqe hero with good options?
Like being tormented for not learning the controls?
Don't care much for a more connected enviroment?
Love to bash other players with everything from a simple sword to a massive burning steel hammer?

well if that's the case i'll think you'll like. But be warned if your a souls fan you might not like some things in this game.

reviewText:
Firstly, a much much better port than the original Dark souls on PC, effort was clearly made here and that's good to see, running at a very smooth 60fps almost constantly and having a good amount of video settings but it shouldn't be hard to run on maximum with a decent computer.

While also having improved keyboard+mouse controls (with a bit of rebinding in the menus) it can be played if not with a little added difficulty in my experience, and so I would still suggest using a controller for this.

The game itself is beautiful having some very pretty landscapes and areas, though something feels a little lacking at times in the design and some enemies and bosses can come off as a bit bland and forgettable but some bosses stick out as rather well made, to summarise some enemy and area design feels as if it could have been better while others are very well made to the point of taking a moment to just look around, unless it's a boss and you get your face caved in for admiring it.

While the series is renowned for it's difficulty any souls veteran won't have a hard time here, some changes were made like more items to restore health but you will lose out on max hp for consecutive deaths without restoring your humanity though as someone who has finished both Dark 1 and Demon's souls I more often than not had at least a dozen humanity on me so if you're pretty good this shouldn't be a concern but can be off putting to those less confident in their ability.

Summoning for co-op feels much easier this time around especially if you grab a certain ring that restricts multiplayer based on a chosen deity to play with your friends, it feels much more responsive and you should see less lag spikes and experience less lag-stabs in pvp, though with the mention of pvp it is possible to finish the game being human a majority of the time and almost never be invaded aside from certain pvp areas which you may pass through which seem like super hot spots this time around.

Overall I think this is a fantastic port and that From Software clearly made an effort this time around to do justice to the platform and would recommend this to any fan of the Souls series though for a starting point if you haven't played a Souls game before I'd sooner recommend the first if purely for the lack of a penalty for death as you learn the mechanics though if you get it on pc, be prepared to look up a couple of mods namely DSfix + DSCfix.

TL;DR:
Great port
Better functioning multiplayer
Similar difficulty to previous entries (personal experience may differ)
Somewhat lacking enemy & area design at times

reviewText:
Praise the Sun!

Dark Souls II, though it may be an easier game (by far) than its predecessors, is all I could have hoped it to be. It's a fun, (if a bit grind-y) challenging hack n' slash, with plenty of backstory and secrets to keep you playing and interested. The first run through may feel a bit too casual for veterans of the series, but NG+ is where the real Dark Souls experience begins.

If you have the patience to run through the game the first time, hopefully the successive playthroughs will be what have you coming back for more.

reviewText:
After 375+ hours of gameplay i though it was time to make a review of this game, probably my favourite one of all time. Let's start:

First of all i'm going to talk about the gameplay:
-Good port to PC, i don't use a ps3/xbox controller, i use the keyboard and mouse and you can play perfectly with that (not like DS1 where it was unplayable).
-Really well optimized, i don't have an outstanding PC and i can play it at 60FPS with all graphic options at the maximum.
-Difficulty of the game is pretty high, and you will die a lot if you are new to the series, but with effort and learing from your deaths you will get through it.

About graphics:
-Despite the downgrade of the graphics from the demo of dark souls to the final game, they are pretty good and really enjoyable
-The scenarios change too much in my opinion, for example, from a poisonous dark zone you go to a iron keep full of lava and fire just by going up with a elevator, but anyways, its so gorgeous you don't even care at all.

About story:
-Brilliant masterpiece, shown in item descriptions and short talks to npc's, maybe its not too deep as it was in DS1 but if you enjoy this kind of story and the soul series" it's still a masterpiece

reviewText:
This game is fun and entertaining, but it requires a good deal of patience and tenacity to get through. Don't expect to do well at all on your first try, just concentrate on achieving one goal and move on from there. The story is similar to DSI In the fact that it's given to you piece meal from item descriptions and the snippets of information you can gather just from looking at your surroundings. The game itself is beautiful and pretty well balanced. The only real flaw that I can garner comes from the multiplayer aspect: Getting invaded randomly by a red completely breaks the immersion. Especially if their name is something along the lines of 420yoloxXexecutionerXxyolo420 and they're wearing havels and the jester chest.

Along similar lines the multiplayer EVERYWHERE THAT ISN'T JAPAN. Suffers from /ridiculous/ lag. You will get backstabbed from across a room. You will get hit by daggers from across a room. You will be hit with projectiles that haven't yet been fired. And the worst part is: there is no disadvantage to being the cause of lag. In fact, some players choose to have their computer overworked to create lag as that lowers the frame rate. And since this is DS lower frame rate = more invincibility frames and less equipment degredation. As a result PvP is an on again off again sort of deal. Its great when it works and its ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed awful when it doesn't.

Don't even get me started on the pvp builds people use. There is nothing more frustrating than a havel clown with great magic barrier spamming laggy resonant souls at you.

7/10
From,
You need to have more than two servers for the entirety of your community, and one of them should not be Japan only. Honestly...

reviewText: Without being a Dark Souls 1 player I absolutely love this game. I bring up Dark Souls 1 because people like to argue the first is better, and that may very well be correct. Without comparing the two, Dark Souls 2 is a great game. It takes a while to get a grip on the hidden story and background but oh my word is it shocking when you figure it out. Combat is absolutely amazing, aside of the auto locked PvE creeps/bosses that always seem to hit you, and PvP is what most (said most) Dark Souls fans love about this game. Some of the scenes/views in Dark Souls 2 are to die for. Even though playing on the mouse and keyboard can be more of a hassle to pull off compared to the controller counter part, controls are still pretty easy to pick up (PvE controls are simple, PvP you might have to do some key bindings or invest in a controller.) I'd recommend this game for any of my friends to play. I love it and spent over 200hours in game, so you might want to give it a try to.

You will be hit with projectiles that haven't yet been fired. And the worst part is: there is no disadvantage to being the cause of lag. In fact, some players choose to have their computer overworked to create lag as that lowers the frame rate. And since this is DS lower frame rate = more invincibility frames and less equipment degredation. As a result PvP is an on again off again sort of deal. Its great when it works and its ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed awful when it doesn't.

Don't even get me started on the pvp builds people use. There is nothing more frustrating than a havel clown with great magic barrier spamming laggy resonant souls at you.

7/10
From,
You need to have more than two servers for the entirety of your community, and one of them should not be Japan only. Honestly...
